content.question: You are in a multi-engine aircraft equipped with counter-rotating propellers, which rotate away from the cockpit when viewed from behind. In the case of an engine failure, which engine is critical?

options.A: There is no critical engine as counter-rotating blades always generate a p-factor closest to the cockpit.
options.B: The left engine is critical.
options.C: The right engine is critical.
options.D: Both engines are critical.

key_points: Note: This question is very poorly written
When both engines rotate "outwards", both engines have a worse effect in the event of an engine failure than if they rotated "inwards"
This does not, however, mean they are both critical
learning.explanation: Note: This question is very poorly written. When both engines rotate "outwards", both engines have a worse effect in the event of an engine failure than if they rotated "inwards". This does not, however, mean they are both critical. A critical engine is one which has a worse effect than the other in the event of an engine failure, so both engines cannot be critical. Nonetheless, we have chosen the option that "both engines are critical" as they both have the worst case thrust asymmetry if an engine fails, and the other options were not correct at all. The critical engine of a multi-engine, fixed-wing propeller-driven aircraft is the one whose failure would result in the most adverse effects on the aircraft's handling and performance. When one of the engines on a typical multi-engine aircraft becomes inoperative, a thrust asymmetry exists. The thrust asymmetry can be different, depending on how the engine is mounted. Particularly on a propeller aircraft, the propellers are subject to the asymmetric blade effect, called P-factor. This occurs because the propeller does not spin perpendicular to the airflow, as the aircraft is flying with an angle of attack. This means that the down-going blades on the propeller have a higher angle of attack and longer track, so they produce more thrust. Therefore, the thrust vector of the engine is located not centrally, but more towards the down-going blade side. The annex above shows an aircraft with both engine rotating to the right. This means that one engine has its thrust vector further from the aircraft's longitudinal axis, and therefore if the other engine fails, it has a worse effect on yaw. This engine (with the worst effect on yaw) is called the critical engine. In the case of this question though, both engines have their thrust vector further from the longitudinal axis, so the aircraft has a worse response from either engine failing. In this question, none of the engines have a P-factor closest to the cockpit. That option is not quite correct in its current form.

How much will the SR change if operating 1000 ft above (1) or 2000 ft below (2) the optimum altitude?

key_points: For a jet aircraft, there is an optimum altitude to operate efficiently, in respect of its speed and thrust required
As gas turbine engines give their best Specific Fuel Consumption at altitude, it is necessary to climb to an altitude where the engine is most efficient and to be flying at VMD, the best range speed
This then, will be the optimum altitude for range flying
learning.explanation: For a jet aircraft, there is an optimum altitude to operate efficiently, in respect of its speed and thrust required. As gas turbine engines give their best Specific Fuel Consumption at altitude, it is necessary to climb to an altitude where the engine is most efficient and to be flying at VMD, the best range speed. This then, will be the optimum altitude for range flying. The best range and maximum endurance are achieved at the Optimum Altitude. Operating at "off-optimum" altitude, incurs both fuel and mileage penalty. In other words, any deviation, above or below, from the optimum altitude will increase fuel consumption and reduce the Specific Range (SR). As an example, you can see also the Table 4.1 in your CAP 697 (Section 4 MRJT1 p.1). The numbers may be different, but is shows a fuel mileage penalty for deviations from optimum altitude. For this question, 1000 ft deviation from the optimum altitude (above or below) incurs an SR reduction by 1.25%, 2000 ft deviation (above or below) an SR reduction by 2 x 1.25% = 2.5% and so on.

Complete the following sentence:
Consider two jet aircraft of the same type. The take-off mass of Jet 1 is 75 000 kg, and for Jet 2 it is 67 000 kg. Jet 1 will have a (1)_____ speed for best angle of climb, and a (2)_____ speed for best rate of climb.

options.A: (1) lower; (2) lower.
options.B: (1) lower; (2) higher.
options.C: (1) higher; (2) higher.
options.D: (1) higher; (2) lower.

key_points: Best Angle of climb speed (VX) is found at the maximum excess of Thrust – in other words, where the gap between the “Thrust” available and Thrust Required “Drag” curves is the greatest
Weight has a very pronounced effect on aircraft performance
If weight is added to an aircraft, it must fly at a higher AOA to maintain a given altitude and speed
learning.explanation: Best Angle of climb speed (VX) is found at the maximum excess of Thrust – in other words, where the gap between the “Thrust” available and Thrust Required “Drag” curves is the greatest. Weight has a very pronounced effect on aircraft performance. If weight is added to an aircraft, it must fly at a higher AOA to maintain a given altitude and speed. This increases the induced drag of the wings, as well as the parasite drag of the aircraft. Increased drag means that additional thrust is needed to overcome it, which in turn means that less reserve thrust is available for climbing. This moves the Total Drag curve up, but also to the right. Thrust Required is increased and VX is a faster IAS. Best Rate of climb speed (VY) is found at the maximum excess of Power – in other words, where the gap between the “Power” available and Power Required curves is the greatest. As weight increases, the power required curve moves up and to the right. As a result, less excess Power is available and, therefore, the rate of climb decreases. However, as you can see, the speed for maximum Excess Power available is higher. Summary: higher Weight => decreased rate of climb => increased VY speed.

learning.explanation: During flight, an aircraft will experience Parasite Drag (proportional to IAS2, increases with increasing “Parasite Area” => flaps, undercarriage or speed brakes) and Induced Drag (inversely proportional to IAS2, increases with increasing weight). The sum of Parasite Drag and Induced Drag is the Total Drag. The Total Drag will be minimum at the IAS where Parasite Drag = Induced Drag. This speed is called Minimum Drag Speed (VMD); => Flying at a slower or faster speed than VMD will generate more drag. When flying at a slower speed than VMD, the aircraft will be in the speed unstable region. Any loss of speed will result in an increase in drag and further speed loss (which must be corrected by an increase in thrust).

Please let us know if you see this question in your exam, thank you. Engine performance relies very heavily on air density. The higher the density of air, the more air that can be mixed with fuel and burnt, creating more power. Higher density = higher performance. High temperature High humidity In other words, hot, high and humid are bad for performance. An increase in humidity will therefore cause a reduction in density. This is different to a temperature increase, which would have a larger effect on a turbine engine, as not only would the air density be lower, but jet engines quickly become temperature limited so they do not go over the maximum TGT (Turbine Gas Temperature), and their thrust output is therefore further reduced by hot temperatures.

content.question: The flight crew of a jet aircraft experiencing ice buildup on pitot probes during the climb fail to recognise the unreliable speed indications and opt to reduce the thrust to control the indicated airspeed (IAS). What could the potential consequence of this be?

options.A: The aircraft will be at increased risk of stalling due to the reduced thrust, exacerbating the situation.
options.B: The autopilot will automatically detect the issue and prevent a dangerous situation from occurring.
options.C: There will be no adverse effects as the aircraft systems are designed to compensate for such discrepancies automatically.
options.D: The aircraft will begin descending and experience a subsequent loss of speed control.

key_points: This is not supposed to be a Performance question, and is much closer to an instrumentation question, but has been reported as seen in Performance exams recently (as well as very similar questions in PoF exams)

If the pitot tubes get blocked in the climb, but the static ports remain free, then the indicated airspeed will initially stop changing with airspeed, and will now gradually increase with altitude as the static pressure reduces (the airspeed indicator now acts like an altimeter)

In the climb, this may not be noticeable for a while, and might not be noticed at all if the autopilot was in certain modes, such as those which maintain a constant rate of climb (assuming constant thrust)
learning.explanation: This is not supposed to be a Performance question, and is much closer to an instrumentation question, but has been reported as seen in Performance exams recently (as well as very similar questions in PoF exams). If the pitot tubes get blocked in the climb, but the static ports remain free, then the indicated airspeed will initially stop changing with airspeed, and will now gradually increase with altitude as the static pressure reduces (the airspeed indicator now acts like an altimeter). In the climb, this may not be noticeable for a while, and might not be noticed at all if the autopilot was in certain modes, such as those which maintain a constant rate of climb (assuming constant thrust). Whatever happens, as the aircraft continues to climb, the actual airspeed is unknown whilst the indicated airspeed (IAS) is showing a continuous increase. This is particularly dangerous in modes such as level change or flight level change, which maintain a constant airspeed/Mach No. in the climb, as the aircraft would pitch up more and more to try to reduce the "increasing airspeed", stalling the aircraft quite quickly. If the aircraft does not stall beforehand, then when maximum airspeed is reached, the pilots or autopilot/autothrottle will either reduce thrust or pitch up to avoid further airspeed increase, which will very quickly lead to a stall. As for the other options, the air data computer, autopilot and autothrottle systems have the same pitot inputs as the pilots do, so will not be able to protect the aircraft from this condition, that is one of the reasons that probe icing and blockages are so dangerous.

learning.explanation: For a multi-engine airplane, the largest asymmetric thrust moment occurs when an outboard engine fails. That engine failure which most adversely affects the performance is deemed the critical power unit and is used to determine the limiting control speeds that will ensure adequate directional control in such an event. content.question: Which of the following statements about performance definitions and safety factors is correct?

options.A: The net and gross climb gradients are equal for a four-engined aeroplane.
options.B: The net climb gradient is the gross climb gradient minus a safety margin.
options.C: The gross take off flight path must clear all obstacles by at least 35 ft.
options.D: The gross climb gradient is the net climb gradient minus a safety margin.

key_points: When aircraft are being certified, the manufacturer must test the aircraft in many different ways to define certain levels of performance for many phases of flight, such as take-off distance, maximum rate of climb, landing distance and many more
There are different types of performance categorisation
Measured Performance is the performance achieved by the manufacturer under test conditions for certification
learning.explanation: When aircraft are being certified, the manufacturer must test the aircraft in many different ways to define certain levels of performance for many phases of flight, such as take-off distance, maximum rate of climb, landing distance and many more. There are different types of performance categorisation. Measured Performance is the performance achieved by the manufacturer under test conditions for certification. It utilises new aeroplanes and the test pilots, and is therefore not representative of the actual performance that any single aircraft might be able to achieve in normal circumstances, flown by a normal pilot. Gross Performance is the expected fleet average of aeroplanes, given that they are sufficiently maintained and flown as per the techniques detailed in the flight manuals, by a normal pilot. This means that any aircraft in the fleet has a 50% chance of exceeding this performance, but also a 50% chance of not meeting this performance. Net Performance is the gross performance, reduced by the safety margin, to account for various possibilities that could commonly cause reduced performance, such as variations in pilot technique, below-average aircraft performance, etc. The safety margin is set so that the chance of an aircraft not meeting the net performance level is extremely low. The safety margin is not fixed, It depends on the likelihood of the situation occurring, and is set to make sure that the total probability of an incident or accident occurring is at least lower than 1 in 1 million, when a passenger buys their ticket (known as their “remote probability”). This might mean that the safety margin (between gross and net performance) is large for likely events such as a take-off with all engines operating, but the safety margin is very low or even zero for unlikely events such as an engine failure at V1.

This occurs because for every minute the aeroplane is in a headwind, the wind is pushing it backward. Therefore, the shorter the time exposed to the wind, the shorter the distance it is pushed back.

learning.explanation: Learning Objective 032.01.05.01.05: Explain the effect of mass, altitude, wind, speed and configuration on the glide descent. Learning Objective 032.04.04.02.01: Describe and explain the factors which affect the en-route net drift-down flight path. We have not been told whether the aircraft is multi-engine or single-engine, but neither is having a good day. In a multi, the procedure is called a drift-down, and is effectively the aircraft losing height as slowly as possible (with the remaining engine(s) running at max continuous thrust), until the aircraft gets low enough to be able to maintain height on the working engine(s). In a single, it is just gliding to the safest place possible. Nonetheless, in both scenarios we want to extend our glide or drift-down range as far as possible. In this case, we would like a tailwind, which can carry us further away from the mountains, and we should fly as close to minimum drag speed as possible. Minimum drag speed (VMD) is the best glide range speed in both a jet and a prop (it doesn't matter what engine they have if it isn't working), and is going to provide a far better glide ratio that going at nearly VMO, which means having a huge amount of drag, and a very steep glide angle.

key_points: Propeller aircraft cannot measure thrust output, only power (Power = Thrust x Velocity)
This means that it is often useful to change thrust required (drag) graphs into power required graphs, by multiplying by speed (TAS) again
The curve looks the same, but if you get to compare them, the power required curve is steeper and a little to the left
learning.explanation: Propeller aircraft cannot measure thrust output, only power (Power = Thrust x Velocity). This means that it is often useful to change thrust required (drag) graphs into power required graphs, by multiplying by speed (TAS) again. The curve looks the same, but if you get to compare them, the power required curve is steeper and a little to the left. This is where it can get a little complicated, as drag graphs are often created with IAS on the X-axis, for easy usage at all altitudes, but Power = Thrust x True Airspeed. This means that for the same thrust required (drag), an increase in altitude causes a higher TAS and therefore a higher power required. There we have it then; for increased altitude, the power required curve will look almost the same, but for each point on the curve (which is a certain IAS), the TAS will be higher (so the curve moves to the right) and therefore the power required will also be higher (so the graph moves upwards). The graph therefore moves upwards and rightwards, away from the origin, so figure (d) is correct.

key_points: RATE OF DESCENT The rate of descent is the vertical speed of an aeroplane, which is usually specified in feet per minute (fpm) and is the vertical component of the forward speed of the aeroplane along the climb path
Rate of descent depends on both the angle of descent and the speed down the flight path
The attached graph shows that there is greater excess drag at high speed than at low speeds
learning.explanation: RATE OF DESCENT The rate of descent is the vertical speed of an aeroplane, which is usually specified in feet per minute (fpm) and is the vertical component of the forward speed of the aeroplane along the climb path. Rate of descent depends on both the angle of descent and the speed down the flight path. The attached graph shows that there is greater excess drag at high speed than at low speeds. The shallowest angle of descent is achieved by staying slow. This means, that the slower speed requires a lower rate of descent to maintain the same descent path. V/S AUTOPILOT MODE Vertical Speed is an autopilot flight guidance vertical mode. In this mode, the Flight Management and Guidance Computer (FMCG) pitch mode guides the aircraft to the target V/S. The corresponding thrust mode is SPEED or MACH. The increase in drag associated with flap deflection requires an increased power setting in order to maintain a given airspeed and attitude, or a steady rate of descent. In conclusion: Using the V/S autopilot mode means that the autopilot is keeping a constant rate of descent. By slowing down, the vertical speed becomes excessive and the pilot must reduce the vertical speed to maintain a constant descent path. After slowing down to the approach speed, the added drag from the configuration will demand more power/thrust from the engines to keep the airspeed constant.

learning.explanation: ICAO Annex 14 Declared distances. a) Take-off run available (TORA). The length of runway declared available and suitable for the ground run of an aeroplane taking off. b) Take-off distance available (TODA). The length of the take-off run available plus the length of the clearway, if provided. c) Accelerate-stop distance available (ASDA). The length of the take-off run available plus the length of the stopway, if provided. d) Landing distance available (LDA). Stopway. A defined rectangular area on the ground at the end of take-off run available prepared as a suitable area in which an aircraft can be stopped in the case of an abandoned take-off.

For a given runway length and airplane weight, selecting a greater flap setting will increase the lift coefficient, which reduces the stalling speed

learning.explanation: EFFECT OF FLAPS ON LANDING/TAKE-OFF RUN AND CLIMB GRADIENT The use of high lift devices (Flaps) will have an impact on the take-off and Landing roll and climb gradient. For a given runway length and airplane weight, selecting a greater flap setting will increase the lift coefficient, which reduces the stalling speed. As a consequence, the take-off speeds are reduced (the same lift will be created at smaller air speed due to greater lift coefficient). This will reduce the take-off run. Flap extension during landings provides several advantages by: producing greater lift and permitting lower landing speed; producing greater drag, permitting a steep descent angle without airspeed increase. => Reducing the length of the landing roll. The down side of the use of flaps is that it generates more parasite drag: We get our best angle of climb and, therefore, our best gradient where there is the biggest gap between the thrust available and thrust required. The parasite drag from the extended flap closes the gap and the climb angle and climb gradient will reduce => go around performance is deteriorated. Hence as soon as we can after take off we accelerate and retract the flap and climb clean. Thus, we can conclude that the best climb gradient will be achieved using the least amount of flaps.

learning.explanation: In a steady descent, thrust is reduced. As a result, the aircraft slows down due to a reduced forward force (Thrust) in comparison to the backward force (Drag). content.question: Which of these combinations would provide the lowest specific fuel consumption (SFC)?

key_points: Note: This should be asking specifically about jet engines, which would fit closest to the learning objectives, and would fit the answer from feedback correctly
Unfortunately, the question does not mention this
We will assume that they are asking about jet engines, but please do tell us in the comments or by email (info@atplquestions
learning.explanation: Note: This should be asking specifically about jet engines, which would fit closest to the learning objectives, and would fit the answer from feedback correctly. Unfortunately, the question does not mention this. We will assume that they are asking about jet engines, but please do tell us in the comments or by email (info@atplquestions.com) if this is the same if you see it in the exam. It may be worth commenting on this in the exam (if available) or appealing if you get it wrong, as it is misleading. Engine efficiency can be measured by a value called the Specific Fuel Consumption. This value tells us how much fuel the engine burns per unit of thrust produced. As we want low fuel burn for high thrust, the lower the SFC, the better. The calculation for SFC is via the formula: SFC = Fuel Flow/Thrust The way to make the SFC lower (more efficient) is by operating the engine in cold temperatures, and at high RPM. The cold temperatures bit of the answer is therefore very simple. However, the best altitude (low or high) requires another step. Above we mentioned that the engine like to run at high RPM to improve SFC. This is the same at all altitudes, but the problem is that the engines are far too powerful to run high RPM at low altitudes, and would quickly cause most jets to overspeed, or just run at very high drag speeds. Therefore, we want to fly at high altitudes, where the high RPM of the engines produces the correct amount of thrust for us to fly at a reasonable cruising speed, with lower drag, and better range (This also coincides with colder temperatures, which are good for SFC). Technically, this doesn't change the SFC much, but practically, it makes a huge difference to our overall efficiency, and our range.

content.question: Which of the following statements is correct during failure of the critical engine?

options.B: VY decreases.

Consequently, the right hand side of the power curve lifts up and VY decreases ( “If flying at VMC, you should be able to maintain heading and altitude with no more than 5° bank
“ Incorrect
learning.explanation: Following the engine failure, there is a progressive increase in parasite drag, which leads to an increase in parasite power (parasite drag x TAS). Consequently, the right hand side of the power curve lifts up and VY decreases ( “If flying at VMC, you should be able to maintain heading and altitude with no more than 5° bank. “ Incorrect. VMC is the calibrated airspeed, at which, when the critical engine is suddenly made inoperative, it is possible to maintain control of the aeroplane with that engine still inoperative, and maintain straight flight with an angle of bank not more than 5º. It does not mention anything about maintaining altitude. “VMC increases with altitude” Incorrect. If asymmetric thrust is high, VMC will be high. Asymmetric thrust is higher at low altitudes, therefore VMC would be expected to decrease with altitude. “Service ceiling remains the same” Incorrect. An engine failure will result in loss of thrust from the failed engine. Parasite drag will also increase – from the rudder and the windmilling engine. learning.explanation: IMPORTANT NOTE: This question was copied from POF following student feedback. However, it appears to be beyond the scope of the Performance syllabus. Please inform us if you encounter this question in your 032 Performance exam. The airframe may become contaminated by ice, frost or water either whilst it is in flight or when standing on the ground. HEAVY RAIN Heavy rain has the following effects on aeroplane performance: - The impingement and rapid accumulation of water sufficiently distorts the shape of the upper wing surface and diminishes the total lift by up to 30% of its normal value. - The impact of the rain on an aeroplane in the landing configuration decreases the aircraft’s forward speed. - When operating in such conditions a jet engine is slow to respond to rapid demands for thrust. - The mass of the rain can increase the aircraft mass momentarily. The total effect of these factors for any aeroplane experiencing such weather conditions is to produce a much lower level of performance. The mass increase raises the stalling speed, whilst the reduced lift and increased drag together reduce the forward speed achieved. An additional consideration, while not affecting stall speed, is the effect of the impact of heavy rain on the aircraft. Momentum will be lost and airspeed will decrease, requiring increased thrust. At the same time, heavy rain will also be driving the aircraft downwards.

options.B: (1) single engine; (2) up to 50% headwind; (3) more than 150% tailwind.
options.C: (1) multi-engine; (2) more than 50% headwind; (3) no less than 150% tailwind.

key_points: The regulations for all classes of aircraft require that in calculating the takeoff distance, no more than 50% of the headwind component is assumed and no less than 150% of a tailwind component is assumed
This is to allow for variations in the reported winds during takeoff
For example, it would not be wise to plan a distance limited takeoff with 10 kt of headwind, in the event that conditions changed at the actual time of takeoff, and the wind became less than 10 kt
learning.explanation: The regulations for all classes of aircraft require that in calculating the takeoff distance, no more than 50% of the headwind component is assumed and no less than 150% of a tailwind component is assumed. This is to allow for variations in the reported winds during takeoff. For example, it would not be wise to plan a distance limited takeoff with 10 kt of headwind, in the event that conditions changed at the actual time of takeoff, and the wind became less than 10 kt. In this case, the aeroplane would not be able to complete the takeoff within the available distance. Most aeroplane performance manuals and operating handbooks already have the wind rules factored into the takeoff graphs or tables. Therefore, simply use the forecast wind and the graph or table whichever is available, and it will automatically correct the takeoff distance to account for the regulation on wind.

content.question: What speed will be limiting with a descent at constant mach?

options.A: MMO
options.B: VMO
options.C: VS
options.D: VNE

key_points: At sea level, the TAS is comparitively low and the speed of sound is quite high
At high altitude (for a given CAS), the TAS is much higher, because the air is thin and the local speed of sound (LSS) is less, because it is colder
Because the Mach number is TAS divided by LSS, this means in turn that at altitude, your Mach number is higher for a given CAS, than it is at low level
learning.explanation: At sea level, the TAS is comparitively low and the speed of sound is quite high. At high altitude (for a given CAS), the TAS is much higher, because the air is thin and the local speed of sound (LSS) is less, because it is colder. Because the Mach number is TAS divided by LSS, this means in turn that at altitude, your Mach number is higher for a given CAS, than it is at low level. The result of this is that, as you climb, the maximum speed is controlled at low level by CAS and VMO, and at altitude you reach your limiting Mach number MMO, before you reach VMO and therefore your maximum speed is controlled by MMO. In the descent the reverse is true. Your maximum speed is controlled by MMO first, and then by VMO at lower altitudes. Alternatively, LSS increases during the descent, due to the rising temperature. Therefore, TAS must increase during descent to maintain constant Mach No. IAS is also increasing and will eventually reach its limit. VMO ("max operating") is the term for the maximum certified IAS. NOTE: You can also advice the ECTM lines to show that IAS increases with constant Mach.

key_points: CLIMB GRADIENT depends on the difference between the thrust and drag (the excess thrust) and the mass of the aircraft
Since weight, altitude, temperature and configuration changes affect excess thrust and power, they also affect climb performance

Climb Gradient = ((Thrust - Drag) / Weight x 100 As described above, one of the factors affecting the climb gradient is the Temperature: Higher the air temperature (decreasing density) will reduce thrust
learning.explanation: CLIMB GRADIENT depends on the difference between the thrust and drag (the excess thrust) and the mass of the aircraft. Since weight, altitude, temperature and configuration changes affect excess thrust and power, they also affect climb performance. Climb Gradient = ((Thrust - Drag) / Weight x 100 As described above, one of the factors affecting the climb gradient is the Temperature: Higher the air temperature (decreasing density) will reduce thrust. As a result, the difference between thrust and drag will be smaller, and therefore the climb gradient reduces. RATE OF CLIMB may be obtained by multiplying the Climb Gradient and TAS (ROC ft/min = TAS kt x Gradient %). As a result, if an increased temperature decreases the Climb Gradient, the Rate of Climb will also decrease.

content.question: What is the effect of an engine failure of a multi-engined piston aeroplane in a steady climb on VX and on the angle of climb, with the propeller of the failed engine in the feathered position?

options.A: VX decreases and the angle of climb increases.
options.B: Both increase.
options.C: VX Increases and the angle of climb decreases.
options.D: Both decrease.

key_points: In a steady climb, the balance of forces is represented by the equation: T = D + W Sin Climb angle
Solving for Sin Climb angle, we get: Sin Climb angle = (T - D) / W
After an engine failure, the thrust available by the remaining engine will be less than the All-Engines-Operating thrust
learning.explanation: In a steady climb, the balance of forces is represented by the equation: T = D + W Sin Climb angle. Solving for Sin Climb angle, we get: Sin Climb angle = (T - D) / W. After an engine failure, the thrust available by the remaining engine will be less than the All-Engines-Operating thrust. Thus, the excess thrust will be also less, with the drag constant because of the feathered position of the propeller of the failed engine and as a consequence the Climb angle will decrease. For a multi-engined piston aeroplane, the Single-Engine VX (VXSE) is likely to be higher than VX. There are several graphical explanations for this increase, that in order to be valid depend on knowing the exact shape of the piston-engine thrust and drag curves, and both of these are extremely hard to find, because piston engine thrust is not easily measured.

content.question: You are on the downwind leg at Addison airport in Texas and you notice you have a significant tailwind. When the final turn/base leg is complete and you are on final, what would you expect to have to do?

options.A: You would expect to have to increase the engine thrust to stay on the correct flight path because with the headwind the ground path will tend to decrease.
options.B: You would expect to have to decrease the engine thrust to stay on the correct flight path because with the headwind the ground path will tend to decrease.
options.C: You would expect to have to decrease the engine thrust to stay on the correct flight path because with the headwind the ground path will tend to increase.
options.D: You would expect to have to increase the engine thrust to stay on the correct flight path because with the headwind the ground path will tend to increase.

key_points: A tailwind in the downwind leg translates into a headwind situation on final (note that you are heading opposite directions)

If no correction to thrust are made, and the pilot uses a "still air" setting, the headwind reduces the groundspeed and the previously calculated still air rate of descent will cause you to descend below the glideslope
Keep in mind the formula for target rate of descent on a 3° glideslope: ROD = 5 x groundspeed
learning.explanation: A tailwind in the downwind leg translates into a headwind situation on final (note that you are heading opposite directions). If no correction to thrust are made, and the pilot uses a "still air" setting, the headwind reduces the groundspeed and the previously calculated still air rate of descent will cause you to descend below the glideslope. Keep in mind the formula for target rate of descent on a 3° glideslope: ROD = 5 x groundspeed. For example, if IAS on final equals 120 kt, the still air groundspeed on final is 120 kt, and the required rate of descent = 5 x 120 = 600 ft/min. Now, if the pilot experiences a headwind of 20 kt, the IAS will equal 120 kt, the groundspeed will be 100 kt, and consequently the required rate of descent = 5 x 100 = 500 ft/min A rate of descent of 500 ft/min requires more thrust/power applied than a 600 ft/min ROD. Therefore, more thrust is required on final with a headwind. The next step is to understand whether the ground path will increase or descrease. If the pilot makes the thrust and rate of descent correction the distance on final will be the same, delivering you to the touchdown point. We can only imagine that EASA is referring to what would happen if the pilot did not correct thrust and ROD for the headwind. In which case, the 600 ft/min, in the above example, would have you land short and cause you to cover a reduced ground distance.

Maximum Endurance Speed is the airspeed at which the aircraft burns the least possible amount of fuel, the minimum drag is produced and the minimum thrust is required, thus the maximum airborne time (maximum endurance) is gained
learning.explanation: Note: This is very similar to question 322651, but it is possible that both may be present in the question banks in different authorities. Endurance is the time that the aircraft can remain airborne. Maximum Endurance Speed is the airspeed at which the aircraft burns the least possible amount of fuel, the minimum drag is produced and the minimum thrust is required, thus the maximum airborne time (maximum endurance) is gained. For turbojet aeroplanes, this Maximum Endurance Speed is the VMD. The Maximum Endurance Speed for propeller aircraft is the VMP (speed for minimum power required, slightly slower than VMD). Unlike range, endurance is not affected by the wind conditions, since it is only affected by the airspeed selection and amount of usable fuel onboard. Also, the Maximum Endurance Speed, as an airspeed, is unaffected by the wind. Remember that the aircraft has no idea that the wind exists, so when staying airborne for as long as possible, the wind is irrelevant.

content.question: Two aircraft of the same weight, configuration and altitude are climbing with the same pitch angle. Assume no compressibility effects and a standard atmosphere. Aircraft A is at Mach 0.75 and aircraft B is at Mach 0.73. Which will have the highest rate of climb?

options.A: Aircraft B
options.B: Not possible to determine, TAS is required
options.C: Aircraft A
options.D: Aircraft A below FL 300, thereafter Aircraft B

key_points: This is quite simple
The two aircraft are pitched at the same angle and aircraft A is flying faster than aircraft B

Not only will aircraft A have a slightly lower angle of attack (due to its higher speed) so therefore will have a slightly higher climb angle, but also it will be travelling up this climb angle at a faster speed, thereby getting a higher rate of climb
learning.explanation: This is quite simple. The two aircraft are pitched at the same angle and aircraft A is flying faster than aircraft B. Not only will aircraft A have a slightly lower angle of attack (due to its higher speed) so therefore will have a slightly higher climb angle, but also it will be travelling up this climb angle at a faster speed, thereby getting a higher rate of climb. The reason we know aircraft A is faster than aircraft B is that it is flying at a higher Mach Number, which directly compares to their TAS by the equation Mach Number = TAS/LSS Where LSS is the Local Speed of Sound - which varies by temperature {LSS = 38.94√(Temperature(K))} Therefore, whatever the local speed of sound is (and it is the same for both aircraft as they are in the same conditions), then the higher Mach Number means a higher TAS.

content.question: When flying in the speed unstable region, what is the relationship between parasite drag and induced drag?

options.A: Parasite drag is greater than induced drag.
options.B: Induced drag is greater than parasite drag.
options.C: Parasite drag and induced drag are exactly the same.
options.D: There is no special relationship between parasite drag and induced drag in the speed unstable region.

key_points: Note: This is a bit of a reach to be considered a Performance question, as the closest Learning Objective for this is in PoF, and the Performance learning objectives would not require this knowledge in our opinion, however, it has been reported in Performance exams
Please let us know if you see this question in any exams, thank you

During flight, an aircraft will experience two types of drag: - Parasite Drag (proportional to IAS2, increases with increasing “Parasite Area”: flaps, undercarriage or speed brakes) - Induced Drag (inversely proportional to IAS2, increases with increasing weight)
learning.explanation: Note: This is a bit of a reach to be considered a Performance question, as the closest Learning Objective for this is in PoF, and the Performance learning objectives would not require this knowledge in our opinion, however, it has been reported in Performance exams. Please let us know if you see this question in any exams, thank you. During flight, an aircraft will experience two types of drag: - Parasite Drag (proportional to IAS2, increases with increasing “Parasite Area”: flaps, undercarriage or speed brakes) - Induced Drag (inversely proportional to IAS2, increases with increasing weight). The sum of Parasite Drag and Induced Drag is the Total Drag. The Total Drag will be minimum at the indicated airspeed where Parasite Drag = Induced Drag. This speed is called Minimum Drag Speed (VMD). At speeds below VMD, the Induced Drag is greater than the Parasite Drag. This is known as the "speed unstable" region, as any reduction in airspeed causes an increase in drag, consequently slowing the aircraft down further, causing more drag, and so on. The opposite is true for a speed increase in this region, reducing drag and allowing the aircraft to speed up even more. Speeds above VMD are "speed stable", as a temporary increase in airspeed causes an increase in drag, which returns the aircraft back to the equilibrium speed. In this "speed stable" region, the parasite drag is greater than the induced drag.

content.question:
An aeroplane is flying over a mountain range and suffers an engine failure. The pilots can choose to descend in two different directions with similar terrain profiles, one direction has a headwind and the other has a tailwind. Which direction should they choose, and which speed should they descend at?

2. The tailwind side.
3. VMD
4. VMO

options.A: 1 and 3
options.B: 2 and 3
options.C: 2 and 4
options.D: 1 and 4

key_points: Learning Objective 032
learning.explanation: Learning Objective 032.01.05.01.05: Explain the effect of mass, altitude, wind, speed and configuration on the glide descent. Learning Objective 032.04.04.02.01: Describe and explain the factors which affect the en-route net drift-down flight path. We have not been told whether the aircraft is multi-engine or single-engine, but neither is having a good day. In a multi, the procedure is called a drift-down, and is effectively the aircraft losing height as slowly as possible (with the remaining engine(s) running at max continuous thrust), until the aircraft gets low enough to be able to maintain height on the working engine(s). In a single, it is just gliding to the safest place possible. Nonetheless, in both scenarios we want to extend our glide or drift-down range as far as possible. In this case, we would like a tailwind, which can carry us further away from the mountains, and we should fly as close to minimum drag speed as possible. Minimum drag speed (VMD) is the best glide range speed in both a jet and a prop (it doesn't matter what engine they have if it isn't working), and is going to provide a far better glide ratio that going at VMO, the maximum operating speed, which means having a huge amount of drag, and a very steep glide angle. content.question: For a jet transport aeroplane, which of the following is the reason for the use of ‘maximum range speed’?

options.A: Minimum drag.
options.B: Longest flight duration.
options.C: Minimum fuel flow.
options.D: Minimum specific fuel consumption.

key_points: Range is “the distance an airplane can travel with a given amount of fuel”
Range will primarily depend on the amount of fuel carried on aboard and the Specific Fuel Consumption (SFC)
SFC is the fuel flow required by the engine to produce a unit of thrust or power
learning.explanation: Range is “the distance an airplane can travel with a given amount of fuel”. Range will primarily depend on the amount of fuel carried on aboard and the Specific Fuel Consumption (SFC). SFC is the fuel flow required by the engine to produce a unit of thrust or power. Specific Range = TAS ÷ (SFC x Drag) Therefore, maximum range will be achieved at the minimum specific fuel consumption. Endurance is the amount of time an aircraft can stay in the air with one load of fuel. Speed for maximum endurance is found where the thrust required to maintain level flight is minimum. Therefore, maximum endurance is achieved at the minimum fuel flow. Minimum FF = Speed for max endurance (VMD for jets) Minimum SFC = Speed for max range (1.32 VMD for jets)

content.question: Which of the following options best describes the relationship between fuel flow and TAS, for propeller-driven aeroplanes?

options.A: With increasing TAS, fuel flow will increase, when flying below the minimum power speed.
options.B: With increasing TAS, fuel flow will increase, when flying above the minimum power speed.
options.C: With increasing TAS, fuel flow will decrease, when flying above the minimum power speed.
options.D: With decreasing TAS, fuel flow will decrease, when flying below the minimum power speed.

key_points: Power required is the product of drag multiplied by the TAS flown: Pwr required = DRAG x TAS
Thus, with increasing TAS, parasite drag increases and as a consequence the power required increases too
The minimum power required is produced when the aircraft is flying with the minimum power required speed (VMP), which exists at the lowest point of the power required curve
learning.explanation: Power required is the product of drag multiplied by the TAS flown: Pwr required = DRAG x TAS. Thus, with increasing TAS, parasite drag increases and as a consequence the power required increases too. The minimum power required is produced when the aircraft is flying with the minimum power required speed (VMP), which exists at the lowest point of the power required curve. For a propeller-driven aircraft, VMP is also the best endurance speed, which gives the minimum power required to maintain level flight and is the point where the product of speed and drag (DRAG x TAS) are at a minimum. Any increase or decrease of the TAS above or below the VMP correspondingly, increases the power required and as a result the fuel flow and decreases the aircraft’s endurance.

FACTORS AFFECTING ENDURANCE SPEED FOR MAXIMUM ENDURANCE Fuel flow for a propeller-driven aeroplane in straight-and-level flight depends on SFC x power required, therefore: For maximum endurance, 1/power required must be maximum. content.question: Having all other conditions the same, taking off from an upward-sloping runway compared to a zero slope runway will result in...

options.B: a decreased take-off distance, and a decreased stopping distance in case of an aborted take-off.
options.C: an increased take-off distance, and a decreased stopping distance in case of an aborted take-off.
options.D: a decreased take-off distance, and an increased stopping distance in case of an aborted take-off.

key_points: Among others, one of the factors affecting the take-off distance required is the runway slope
If the runway slopes downhill, the aircraft will be easier to accelerate, assisted by a component of the aircraft weight acting downhill and the distance to V1 and to rotate will be reduced
While, an uphill slope makes the aircraft more difficult to accelerate, since the component of the aircraft weight is now added to the drag
learning.explanation: Among others, one of the factors affecting the take-off distance required is the runway slope. If the runway slopes downhill, the aircraft will be easier to accelerate, assisted by a component of the aircraft weight acting downhill and the distance to V1 and to rotate will be reduced. While, an uphill slope makes the aircraft more difficult to accelerate, since the component of the aircraft weight is now added to the drag. Thus, the distance to V1 and to rotate will be increased and as a result the take-off distance increases too. Also, if the runway slopes downhill, it will be harder to stop, while if the runway slopes uphill, it will be easier. Therefore, in case of an aborted take-off, the stopping distance decreases. content.question: For a jet aircraft, which of these statements is true regarding best range with altitude?

options.A: Best range increases steadily with altitude.
options.B: Best range decreases steadily with altitude.
options.C: Best range increases up to an optimum altitude, then decreases after that.
options.D: Best range is achieved at lower altitudes.

key_points: Jet engines are most efficient at about 90% N1, which is their version of RPM, meaning that they are at 90% of their maximum N1
The airframe of an aircraft has a best range speed too
For jet aircraft, it is 1
learning.explanation: Jet engines are most efficient at about 90% N1, which is their version of RPM, meaning that they are at 90% of their maximum N1. The airframe of an aircraft has a best range speed too. For jet aircraft, it is 1.32 x VMD, where there is the highest indicated airspeed to drag ratio. To get the most efficient jet cruising level, we just have to find the point at which these two values match up, when the engines are running at around 90% N1 and the aircraft is maintaining 1.32VMD. If we ran a modern jet aircraft at 90% N1 near the ground, it would quickly overspeed, as jets are so powerful. Our best range speed at this altitude would be at a low power setting, which is not efficient. Jet engines produce less thrust with higher altitude due to the lower air density, so at the high cruising altitudes of 35 - 42 000 ft is where the engine efficiency peak usually matches up with the best range speed. Flying higher than the optimum altitude does begin to reduce the range though, as the engine is running just above its peak efficiency zone, though even at maximum altitude, most modern jet aircraft are very close to peak efficiency. The extra beauty of this high altitude cruise is the high TAS (True Airspeed), which is much larger than the IAS at high altitudes. Therefore, the best range in a jet increases with altitude up to the optimum altitude, then begins to decrease again.

content.question: During a nighttime departure from an airport in a warm desert area, regulations specify a rate of climb (ROC) of 1600 feet per minute (fpm). However, during the climb, the actual ROC reduces as low as 1200 fpm. What could be the reason for this?

options.A: An inversion causes warmer air at higher altitudes, reducing ROC.
options.B: An inversion causes cooler air at higher altitudes, reducing ROC.
options.C: Pressure altitude variations affect engine performance and reduce ROC.
options.D: Pressure altitude variations affect engine performance and increase ROC.

key_points: On a night of clear skies with calm or light surface wind, a temperature inversion can form due to surface cooling - which can lead to windshear
Temperature inversion is defined as a condition where the temperature increases with an increase in altitude
Strong inversions are known to happen in desert areas, where the surface will heat up quickly during the day and cool off rapidly at night
learning.explanation: On a night of clear skies with calm or light surface wind, a temperature inversion can form due to surface cooling - which can lead to windshear. Temperature inversion is defined as a condition where the temperature increases with an increase in altitude. Strong inversions are known to happen in desert areas, where the surface will heat up quickly during the day and cool off rapidly at night. Due to the temperature inversion, vertical mixing is inhibited - meaning that below an inversion, the wind speed will be light, and the wind just above the inversion may be relatively strong => wind shear develops between the calm winds below and the stronger winds above. This wind shear can cause airspeed fluctuations as an aircraft climbs or descends through the inversion. - Depending on the direction that the pilot decides to take off, the wind shift, at the top of the inversion, may change the headwind into a tailwind => which causes IAS to decrease - leading to a decrease in Rate of Climb. The fluctuation in airspeed could also induce a stall precariously close to the ground. - Furthermore, all performance is based on density altitude and temperature is a key factor. The higher the temperature, the higher the density altitude, the thinner the air and the less performance from your engines (and wings, etc). Since, as we climb through an inversion, temperature increases with an increase in height => we will experience a decreases aircrafts performance leading to a decrease in thrust and lift, as we climb into warmer and less dense air - which reduces the aircraft's rate of climb. This question came from slightly broken feedback, but is in line with at least two other very similar questions. If the examiner does not mention nighttime, then please look out for the answer with density altitude, as the high daytime temperatures induce a high density altitude (low air density), with the high temperatures being particularly bad for jet engines, which lose a lot of thrust in these conditions.

content.question:
Which of the following statements are correct/incorrect regarding VY in a climb with one engine inoperative?
(1) Following an engine failure, VY decreases, becoming VYSE.
(2) VYSE expressed as a true air speed will increase during the climb.

options.A: (1) is correct; (2) is correct.
options.B: (1) is incorrect; (2) is correct.
options.C: (1) is correct; (2) is incorrect.
options.D: (1) is incorrect; (2) is incorrect.

key_points: In the climb, if one of the engines is lost, then the power available is now reduced by half, some slipstream induced lift is lost, and drag is increased due to a stopped or windmilling propeller
This significantly reduces the rate of climb, and in some light piston twins, requires very precise flying to climb at all
That was the easy bit of the question though, and now we have to work out what happens to VY, our best rate of climb speed (now called VYSE as the aircraft is single engine)
learning.explanation: In the climb, if one of the engines is lost, then the power available is now reduced by half, some slipstream induced lift is lost, and drag is increased due to a stopped or windmilling propeller. This significantly reduces the rate of climb, and in some light piston twins, requires very precise flying to climb at all. That was the easy bit of the question though, and now we have to work out what happens to VY, our best rate of climb speed (now called VYSE as the aircraft is single engine). Theoretically, VYSE will be lower than VY, because the extra drag that is caused by the stopped/windmilling propeller is parasite drag, which increases with the square of speed. This increases the parasite drag in the total drag curve, and therefore moves the whole curve up and to the left (for propeller aircraft we usually use power required/power available graphs but the same thing happens there too). This means that VYSE should be lower that VY, as the tangent point goes to the left, so VY decreases when an engine fails. This is not always the case in practice, as a lot of aircraft use the same speed for both VY and VYSE, whether that is to make it simpler to remember, or to add a little extra safety margin, stopping pilots getting below VYSE with an engine out, which is incredibly dangerous, or just because the drag curve does not change that much. As for statement (2), the VY speed is an indicated air speed (IAS), and remains constant with altitude, so as altitude increases, the TAS of this speed will increase due to the reducing air density.

content.question: An aircraft is climbing at a maximum climb angle with constant speed and thrust. Consider for theoretical purposes that the weight of the aircraft suddenly decreases but the flight otherwise continues as normal. For the pilot to maintain the same speed, all factors remaining the same, the angle of climb must be…

options.A: Reduced, to increase the backward component of weight in order to exceed the excess thrust.
options.B: Reduced, to reduce the backward component of weight in order to match the excess thrust.
options.C: Increased, to increase the backward component of weight in order to match the excess thrust.
options.D: Increased, to reduce the backward component of weight in order to be less than the excess thrust.

key_points: The balance of forces in a steady climb shows that thrust is acting upwards and an element of weight (backward component of weight) is adding to the total drag
As the thrust assists the lift, the lift required is less in level flight, thus less lift is required in a climb than in level flight

For a steady speed to be maintained, the thrust and the two retarding effects of the aerodynamic drag (induced and parasite drag) and the weight element must be equal: T = D + Wsinγ (where γ, the climb angle)
learning.explanation: The balance of forces in a steady climb shows that thrust is acting upwards and an element of weight (backward component of weight) is adding to the total drag. As the thrust assists the lift, the lift required is less in level flight, thus less lift is required in a climb than in level flight. For a steady speed to be maintained, the thrust and the two retarding effects of the aerodynamic drag (induced and parasite drag) and the weight element must be equal: T = D + Wsinγ (where γ, the climb angle). Solving for sinγ, we get: sinγ = (T-D)/W, which shows that the climb angle depends on the excess thrust (T-D) and the weight. Thus, the speed for best angle of climb (VX) will be where the excess thrust is greatest. A decrease in mass, decreases the lift induced drag, increasing the excess thrust. Therefore, so as to match the excess thrust and keep it constant, the total drag must be increased by increasing the backward component of weight, which is added to the drag. And since the sinγ is inversely proportional to the weight, as weight decreases the climb angle increases.

content.question: For a turbojet aircraft, what is the difference between range and endurance speeds? Maximum range is flown at...

options.C: 1.32 VMP minimum power speed and maximum endurance is flown at VMP.
options.D: 1.32 VMD minimum drag speed and maximum endurance is flown at VMD.

key_points: The speed to fly a turbojet for maximum range depends on the aerodynamic considerations; TAS divided by drag
Since range is maximum when the ratio of TAS to drag is maximum, flying relatively fast but with as little drag as possible is ideal
The above graph shows that although drag is minimum at VMD, the forward speed is only moderate
learning.explanation: The speed to fly a turbojet for maximum range depends on the aerodynamic considerations; TAS divided by drag. Since range is maximum when the ratio of TAS to drag is maximum, flying relatively fast but with as little drag as possible is ideal. The above graph shows that although drag is minimum at VMD, the forward speed is only moderate. The ratio of TAS to drag is actually greatest at the tangent to the drag curve, which is at 1.32 times the speed for minimum drag. At this speed, a considerably greater TAS is achieved for only a small increase in drag. Having discovered that a turbojet should be flown at the tangent to the drag curve, which can also be described as 1.32 VMD, the effect of altitude on range must be considered. For endurance to be greatest, L/D must be greatest, which means drag must be minimum. Therefore, to fly for maximum endurance, fly at the minimum drag speed, VMD. Practically, however, it is normal to fly slightly faster than VMD to gain speed stability. Because the drag curve is so shallow at the bottom, flying slightly faster than VMD results in only slightly more drag and, therefore, thrust required and fuel flow. The small reduction in endurance is then operationally offset by the benefits of speed stability. However, turbojet endurance is always maximum at VMD.

That was the easy bit of the question though, and now we have to work out what happens to VY, our best rate of climb speed (now called VYSE as the aircraft is single engine) Theoretically, VYSE should be lower than VY, because the extra drag that is caused by the stopped/windmilling propeller is parasite drag, which increases with the square of speed. content.question: If all other factors remain the same, how does the minimum glide angle of an aircraft change with an increase in mass?

options.A: It decreases if the airspeed increases.
options.B: It remains constant, but with an increased airspeed.
options.C: It increases if the airspeed increases.
options.D: It is not possible to say, as it differs between jet and propeller aircraft.

key_points: The best glide angle occurs at VMD, flying at this speed will give the best range in a glide

Glide angle (and glide range) itself is independent of aircraft mass - provided the aircraft glides at VMD, since it is the lift over drag (L/D) ratio that determines the gliding range and it is unchanged with mass
As an aircraft only needs to produce enough lift to counteract weight, the best lift to drag ratio therefore comes when drag is lowest (VMD)
learning.explanation: The best glide angle occurs at VMD, flying at this speed will give the best range in a glide. Glide angle (and glide range) itself is independent of aircraft mass - provided the aircraft glides at VMD, since it is the lift over drag (L/D) ratio that determines the gliding range and it is unchanged with mass. As an aircraft only needs to produce enough lift to counteract weight, the best lift to drag ratio therefore comes when drag is lowest (VMD). If the mass increases, so does the lift, as well as the drag (due to induced drag), so L/D ratio stays the same, and glide angle therefore stays the same. Due to the movement of the drag curve, though, the speed of VMD will also increase. GLIDING DISTANCE Wind speed is an important practical influence on gliding distance over the surface. The mass of an aircraft will not change the gliding angle/range. With a tailwind, the glide distance achieved will be increased as a result of the increased groundspeed. Whereas with a headwind, it will be reduced because of the consequently slower groundspeed. GLIDING TIME The aircraft's mass changes the time the aircraft will glide for. The heavier the aircraft is, the higher the airspeed must be to obtain the same glide ratio (higher VMD). Therefore, heavier aircraft have a shorter gliding time. If two aircraft have the same L/D ratio but different weights and start a glide from the same altitude, the heavier aircraft gliding at a higher airspeed will arrive at the same touchdown point in a shorter time. However, both aircraft will cover the same distance but the lighter one will take a longer time to do so.

learning.explanation: Vertical Speed is an autopilot flight guidance vertical mode. In this mode, the Flight Management and Guidance Computer (FMCG) pitch mode guides the aircraft to the target V/S. The corresponding thrust mode is SPEED or MACH. The V/S guidance has priority over the speed guidance. If the selected target V/S is too high (relative to the current thrust condition and speed), the FMGC will steer the aircraft to the target V/S, but the aircraft will also accelerate or decelerate. As altitude increases and the air gets thinner, the IAS will reduce for a given pitch setting. Consequently, the angle of attack also reduces. As a result, the vertical speed will reduce for a certain pitch attitude. The autopilot will therefore chase the selected vertical speed by pitching up. This results in further decreased IAS. Ultimately, this could lead to a stall.

key_points: The clearway is described in EU-OPS, as a defined rectangular area on the ground or water under the control of the appropriate authority, selected or prepared as a suitable area over which an aeroplane may take a portion of its initial climb to a specified height
The clearway may be load bearing or not

learning.explanation: The clearway is described in EU-OPS, as a defined rectangular area on the ground or water under the control of the appropriate authority, selected or prepared as a suitable area over which an aeroplane may take a portion of its initial climb to a specified height. The clearway may be load bearing or not. The clearway is expressed in terms of a clearway plane with a minimum width of 500 feet (or 152 metres), extending from the end of the runway with an upward slope not exceeding 1.25%, above which no object or terrain protrudes. However, threshold lights may protrude above the plane, if their height above the end of the runway is 0.66 metres (or 26 inches) or less and if they are located to each side of the runway. Also, the clearway may not be greater than 50% of the TORA and should extend at least 75 metres either side of the centre line. The TORA (Take-Off Run Available) plus the clearway make the TODA (Take-Off Distance Available).

options.A: (1) increase; (2) reduce; (3) increase
options.B: (1) reduce; (2) increase; (3) reduce
options.C: (1) increase; (2) reduce; (3) reduce
options.D: (1) reduce; (2) increase; (3) increase

key_points: The elements of the atmosphere: temperature, pressure and humidity directly influence the density of the air
Reduced QNH means lower pressure and in combination with high temperature makes the air less dense
This situation could be expressed as a higher density altitude
learning.explanation: The elements of the atmosphere: temperature, pressure and humidity directly influence the density of the air. Reduced QNH means lower pressure and in combination with high temperature makes the air less dense. This situation could be expressed as a higher density altitude. The above situation results in reduced thrust production and thus a degraded performance. The target threshold speed is an IAS and will be the same for all combinations of pressure and temperature. The true ground speed is based on the TAS, plus or minus the wind component. If the air density is low, because of the low pressure (reduced QNH), the TAS will be higher for a given IAS. Also, the groundspeed will be higher, resulting in an increase of the landing distance required. Generally, climb gradient is expressed by the formula: % Climb Gradient = ((T - D) x 100) / W. With reduced thrust, because of the less dense air, the excess of thrust (T - D) decreases. So, with constant weight and drag, the climb gradient reduces too.

It is important to be able to distinguish between gross and net performance when answering these questions, described in short here: Gross Performance is the expected average performance of an aircraft flown normally by a normal pilot, so any aircraft in the fleet has a 50% chance of exceeding this performance, but also a 50% chance of not meeting this performance
learning.explanation: CS-25 and CS-23 are the documents dictating the specifications aircraft must meet for certification. It includes performance definitions and necessary calculations to assure safety, such as calculations of the take-off flight path. It is important to be able to distinguish between gross and net performance when answering these questions, described in short here: Gross Performance is the expected average performance of an aircraft flown normally by a normal pilot, so any aircraft in the fleet has a 50% chance of exceeding this performance, but also a 50% chance of not meeting this performance. Net Performance is the gross performance, reduced by the safety margin, to account for various possibilities that could commonly cause reduced performance, such as variations in pilot technique, below-average aircraft performance, etc. The safety margin is set so that the chance of an aircraft not meeting the net performance level is extremely low, and varies based on the likelihood of a particular scenario occurring. For this question, you must notice that they are asking about the "take-off flight path", not the "net take-off flight path", which is the "take-off flight path" reduced by a safety margin. The "take-off flight path" is a gross flight path, so the average of the fleet, without any safety margin applied.

content.question: How does the Specific Range (SR) vary, in a propeller-driven aeroplane?

options.A: SR and SFC (Specific Fuel Consumption) decrease slowly with altitude up to full throttle height.
options.B: SR decreases slowly with altitude up to throttle height.
options.C: SR and SFC (Specific Fuel Consumption) increase slowly with altitude up to full throttle height.
options.D: SR increases slowly with altitude up to full throttle height.

key_points: Learning Objective 032
learning.explanation: Learning Objective 032.01.03.02.02: Define a propeller-driven aeroplane’s SFC and describe how it affects fuel flow and specific range. Specific range is a measure of the distance gone per unit of fuel burned. Therefore you could calculate it as Distance/Fuel burned, or by dividing these both by time, you get Speed/Fuel Flow. For Specific Air Range (SAR), which is the SR unaffected by wind, the calculation is: SAR = TAS / Fuel Flow The speed to fly to get maximum SAR is the best range speed, of course. This is because the best range speed gets the highest speed for the lowest thrust (jet) or power (prop), which means it gets the highest speed for lowest fuel burn. In a prop aircraft this is VMD and in a jet it is 1.32 x VMD. This question is not asking about speeds though. This question is asking about what altitude provides the best SAR, specifically in a propeller aircraft. As the options all mention full throttle height, we are going to assume it is a piston engine (not a turboprop). The increase in efficiency with altitude in a prop is not even close to that of a jet, and totally depends on the speeds/power settings flown. Unfortunately, this question is very vague, so we are having to make some rather large assumptions. If we make the assumption that we are cruising at best range speed, which is an indicated air speed, and with the most efficient cruise RPM set for that speed, then we can say that at higher altitudes, the TAS will be higher, but the fuel flow the same (or slightly reduced), up until the full throttle height. Remember that piston engines will also be more efficient with open throttles, for the same power output. This all means that specific air range increases with increasing altitude until the full throttle height for the best range speed, which is the most efficient altitude. Above the full throttle height, the SAR begins to reduce, as the aircraft can no longer maintain the best range speed even with maximum power, due to the low air density. Two options can be removed immediately, because the Specific Fuel Consumption (SFC) in an aircraft is a measure of fuel burn per unit of thrust (or power in a prop), of which a lower value is more efficient, and the SAR is the opposite, where a higher value is most efficient. They would therefore not go the same way (It is actually possible for them to go the same way, because of how they each measure efficiency, but not in this scenario).

options.B: VMD with flaps.

key_points: Minimum drag speed (VMD) is the speed at which induced and profile drag values are equal
It is also the speed that has the lowest total drag penalty, VMD = minimum drag speed Therefore, this speed also represents the best lift-drag ratio (best aerodynamic efficiency)
And because minimum aircraft drag requires minimum thrust (i
learning.explanation: Minimum drag speed (VMD) is the speed at which induced and profile drag values are equal. It is also the speed that has the lowest total drag penalty, VMD = minimum drag speed Therefore, this speed also represents the best lift-drag ratio (best aerodynamic efficiency). And because minimum aircraft drag requires minimum thrust (i.e., thrust = drag), and given that thrust is a product of engine power and fuel consumption is a function of engine power used, the aircraft thus has its lowest fuel consumption in terms of fuel used per hour. Hence it produces the maximum endurance flight time for a given quantity of fuel. In this case, to minimise fuel consumption, the pilot should maintain altitude, keep the aircraft clean and reduce the speed to VMD.

content.question: For a propeller aircraft, the maximum endurance speed in a glide descent in still air is (1) _____ and is (2) _____ by the presence of a headwind.

options.A: (1) VMP; (2) increased
options.B: (1) VMP; (2) unchanged
options.C: (1) VMD; (2) unchanged
options.D: (1) VMD; (2) increased

key_points: An aircraft's glide angle for longest range is decided by it's lift to drag ratio, and given that lift just needs to equal weight (slightly less than weight in a glide - but still a constant value), the only deciding factor is drag
Therefore, an aircraft glides the longest distance (the shallowest glide angle) when drag is lowest, so at VMD, minimum drag speed
Should, for any reason, the aircraft want to remain in the air for a longer time, they can descend at the best glide endurance speed
learning.explanation: An aircraft's glide angle for longest range is decided by it's lift to drag ratio, and given that lift just needs to equal weight (slightly less than weight in a glide - but still a constant value), the only deciding factor is drag. Therefore, an aircraft glides the longest distance (the shallowest glide angle) when drag is lowest, so at VMD, minimum drag speed. Should, for any reason, the aircraft want to remain in the air for a longer time, they can descend at the best glide endurance speed. By flying slightly slower than VMD, the aircraft has slightly more drag, so a steeper descent angle, but is flying down that angle at a much reduced speed, overall leading to a lesser rate of descent, and a longer time in the air. This reduced speed for best endurance in a glide is VMP, the speed for minimum power required. It is not affected by what type of engine the aircraft has, because this is a glide descent, so the engine is not functioning. It is also not affected by headwinds or tailwinds, as they do not increase or decrease rate of descent, they only change where the aircraft will eventually meet the surface, not how long the descent will take.

content.question: For a propeller aeroplane with a naturally aspirated engine (not turbocharged), how does the maximum TAS in level flight vary with increasing altitude? The maximum achievable TAS will...

options.B: increase linearly with a tailwind component.
options.C: decrease steadily.
options.D: increase steadily.

key_points: MAXIMUM SPEED If the thrust available exceeds the thrust required in level flight, then the aeroplane will climb, unless the throttles/thrust levers are adjusted to maintain level flight
If level flight is maintained using the control column and trimmers without adjusting the throttles/thrust levers, the aeroplane will accelerate
Consequently, initially, the drag starts to decrease until VMD
learning.explanation: MAXIMUM SPEED If the thrust available exceeds the thrust required in level flight, then the aeroplane will climb, unless the throttles/thrust levers are adjusted to maintain level flight. If level flight is maintained using the control column and trimmers without adjusting the throttles/thrust levers, the aeroplane will accelerate. Consequently, initially, the drag starts to decrease until VMD. Thereafter, it starts to increase again until it reaches a point where Drag (thrust required) equals Thrust available. At this point, the aircraft is unable to accelerate and will maintain the speed. The maximum speed (VMAX) has been reached => this is shown as the intersection of the "available" and "required" curves. As altitude increases, the air becomes less dense. Thus, thrust available reduces. Consequently, VMAX decreases. As altitude increases, a standard piston engine will deliver less power. Thus, power available reduces. C onsequently, VMAX will also decrease.

content.question:
Determine the Specific Range (SR), given:
Fuel flow: 28 Imp Gal/hr
Specific gravity: 0.72
TAS: 154 MPH

options.A: 1.67 NM air distance / kg.
options.B: 0.68 NM air distance / kg.
options.C: 1.46 NM air distance / kg.
options.D: 2.4 NM air distance / kg.

key_points: The Specific Range (SR) of an aircraft is defined as the number of nautical miles it can fly using a unit of fuel (i
e = NM / 1 kg fuel)
1) Convert IMP GAL into kg: 1 Imp GAL = 4
learning.explanation: The Specific Range (SR) of an aircraft is defined as the number of nautical miles it can fly using a unit of fuel (i.e = NM / 1 kg fuel). 1) Convert IMP GAL into kg: 1 Imp GAL = 4.546 l 28 Imp GAL = 28 x 4.546 = 127.3 l The conversion between fuel volume and mass is very simple: fuel volume in litres × Specific Gravity (density) = fuel mass in kg. 127.3 l x 0.72 = 91.7 kg 2) Convert MPH (Statute miles per hour) into KT (Nautical miles per hour): 1 MPH = 0.8689 NM 154 MPH = 154 x 0.8689 = 133.8 kt 3) Calculate the distance covered per 1 kg of fuel: To cover 133.8 NM, the aircraft burns 91.7 kg of fuel. Therefore, on 1 kg of fuel the aircraft covers: 133.8 NM / 91.7 kg = 1.46 NM SR = 1.46 NM / kg

content.question: Which of the following conditions give the highest Specific Range?

options.A: High altitude, high temperature
options.B: Low altitude, low temperature
options.C: High altitude, low temperature
options.D: Low altitude, high temperature

key_points: Note: This question and answer seem to be referring to jet aircraft, but it does not specify that in the question
As jet engines and piston engines vary so much, in the way that their SFCs and SRs change with altitude and temperature, we will only look at this question through the eyes of jet engines
It might be worth appealing this in the exam if it shows up in exactly this way, as it is ambiguous and quite easily misleading
learning.explanation: Note: This question and answer seem to be referring to jet aircraft, but it does not specify that in the question. As jet engines and piston engines vary so much, in the way that their SFCs and SRs change with altitude and temperature, we will only look at this question through the eyes of jet engines. It might be worth appealing this in the exam if it shows up in exactly this way, as it is ambiguous and quite easily misleading. Please send us any exam feedback about this question, either in the comments or emailed to info@atplquestions.com. thank you! Specific Range (SR) is one of the measures of efficiency for an aircraft, as it is the distance the aircraft can fly per unit of fuel used (higher is better). The easiest formula for it is: Specific Range = TAS/Fuel Flow There is another value similar to this which measures the engine efficiency, and that is the Specific Fuel Consumption (SFC), measuring the fuel used to create each unit of thrust (lower is better). For a jet engine, the formula for it is: Specific Fuel Consumption = Fuel Flow/Thrust Putting the two together with a little rearranging, we can get the formula: SR = TAS/(SFC x Thrust) Aircraft engines are most efficient (low SFC) in cold temperatures and running at high RPM. Aircraft aerodynamics have the best range when flying at the speed for highest IAS to drag ratio, which is the speed 1.32 x VMD. We can call it the best range speed. To make these two high efficiency zones match up, the optimum conditions for jet aircraft are at high altitudes, when the jet engines have to run at around 90% RPM (in efficient cold air) to maintain the best drag speed. This also provides a very high TAS due to the low density, optimising the Specific Range formula above (high TAS, low SFC, low thrust).

Consequently, it will take longer to travel the horizontal distance from TOD
learning.explanation: Once in the air the headwind works against the aircraft's progress: The groundspeed of the aircraft is equal to its airspeed minus the headwind, so for instance, for a 10 kt headwind, while you're cruising at 100 knots airspeed you're only making 90 knots over the ground. So: Sin y = T / (m x g) – D/L Climb gradient = (T / (m x g) – D/L) x 100 With regards to this question, Climb gradient = (236000 / (67000 x 10) – 1/9) x 100 = 24

learning.explanation: EASA AIR OPS Annex I to VIII "Contaminated runway". "Wet runway."
