key_points: Before the days of FMS, the buffet boundary was displayed on a chart
The buffet boundary has both low and high speed limits: The low speed buffet boundary describes the IAS at which we find the onset of the pre-stall buffet at a 10% margin above VS
The high speed buffet boundary describes the IAS at which we find the onset of Mach related buffet, normally MMO, but sometimes slightly below that
learning.explanation: Before the days of FMS, the buffet boundary was displayed on a chart. The buffet boundary has both low and high speed limits: The low speed buffet boundary describes the IAS at which we find the onset of the pre-stall buffet at a 10% margin above VS. The high speed buffet boundary describes the IAS at which we find the onset of Mach related buffet, normally MMO, but sometimes slightly below that. At low altitudes, these speeds are far apart, leaving a wide range of operating speeds. Although stalling IAS remains constant at first as altitude increases, it starts to increase at higher altitude. Also, the IAS at which we get Mach buffet will steadily decrease, because TAS increases in the climb and local speed of sound decreases. The two buffet boundaries will move closer toogether and eventually meet at an altitude where no margins exists, the coffin corner or aerodynamic ceiling, i.e. you cannot fly faster or slower because you will either stall or hit MMO. The right-hand limit on the graph shows the maximum indicated airspeed VMO and then at high altitude the maximum Mach number, MMO. The left-hand limit is based on the stall speed, 1.1 VS. Therefore, with increasing altitude, the low-speed buffet will increase and the high-speed buffet will decrease.

content.question: Regarding a piston engine, how will the fuel flow be affected with increasing altitude while maintaining the same power setting?

learning.explanation: As altitude increases, the air density decreases, which means there is less oxygen available for combustion. Therefore, less fuel is required to maintain a constant power output. So, the fuel flow will decrease, not increase. Increasing the fuel flow in an effort to compensate for the decrease in air density would result in an over-rich mixture and potentially cause engine damage. What exactly do they mean by "maintaining the same power setting?". We believe it is referring to the amount of power the pilot is requesting from the engine, not the actual power output of the engine. In order to maintain the same power setting, the pilot will likely have to lean the mixture (decrease the fuel flow) to compensate for the decrease in air density at higher altitude. So, even though the pilot is requesting the same amount of power, the engine will produce less power due to the decrease in air density, and the fuel flow will decrease to match the decrease in oxygen available. Note: We are deciding that "power setting" means constant RPM/MAP for this question. Please let us know if you come across this question in your official exam.

key_points: To start with, we can assume that the jet aircraft is flying for best range, and when the temperature decreases, the aircraft continues to fly for best range

The decrease in temperature is good for a jet engine's specific fuel consumption, and cold temperatures and high RPM operation both count to decreasing the engine's specific fuel consumption, which allows it to produce more thrust per kg of fuel burnt

Specific Range = TAS/Fuel Flow and Fuel Flow = SFC x Drag So as the aircraft's SFC has decreased, and the Drag has remained the same (jets cruise at constant Mach numbers and when only the temperature changes, the IAS also remains constant), so Fuel Flow has decreased
learning.explanation: To start with, we can assume that the jet aircraft is flying for best range, and when the temperature decreases, the aircraft continues to fly for best range. The decrease in temperature is good for a jet engine's specific fuel consumption, and cold temperatures and high RPM operation both count to decreasing the engine's specific fuel consumption, which allows it to produce more thrust per kg of fuel burnt. Specific Range = TAS/Fuel Flow and Fuel Flow = SFC x Drag So as the aircraft's SFC has decreased, and the Drag has remained the same (jets cruise at constant Mach numbers and when only the temperature changes, the IAS also remains constant), so Fuel Flow has decreased. Now we can also say that TAS will decrease, as the density has increased. That means that both the top of the Specific Range equation (TAS) has decreased, and the bottom (Fuel Flow) has also decreased. We do not have exact figures, so how can we work out what the overall effect is? We know from the integrated range tables in the flight planning CAP (697) that a decrease in temperature causes a decrease in fuel consumption over the distances involved in the table, meaning the effect on specific fuel consumption must be the greater effect, and cold temperatures increase specific range. Now the question does not mention this, but with this colder temperature, the aircraft (ATC notwithstanding) will have a slightly higher optimum altitude, and at that altitude, will gain even higher efficiencies from this temperature drop if it able to climb to this higher altitude. options.B: Rate of Climb will increase and TAS will decrease.

key_points: M = TAS ÷ LSS If the Mach number is constant at M0
76, it means that the above equation needs to be balanced

learning.explanation: M = TAS ÷ LSS If the Mach number is constant at M0.76, it means that the above equation needs to be balanced. content.question: In straight and level flight at a constant IAS and ignoring compressibility effects, changing which of the following would change the amount of induced drag?

options.A: Altitude
options.B: Aircraft weight
options.C: Tailwind
options.D: Headwind

key_points: The total drag is the resulting factor if you add induced drag and parasite drag together
Parasite drag is the simple one, that we know instinctively
It is the result of form drag and skin friction drag, and is what a car has to overcome (as well as road friction) when it drives along a flat road
learning.explanation: The total drag is the resulting factor if you add induced drag and parasite drag together. Parasite drag is the simple one, that we know instinctively. It is the result of form drag and skin friction drag, and is what a car has to overcome (as well as road friction) when it drives along a flat road. Parasite increases with the square of the airspeed, so gets very high when aircraft fly fast. Induced drag is more complex. Its full name is "lift-induced drag", and occurs due to our wings re-directing the airflow downwards. The pressure differential (high below, low above) caused by our wing's shape (aerofoil) makes the air want to take a shortcut around the wingtip, which creates sideways movement of air, and creates vortices of air around the wing. To cut an incredibly long explanation short, this energy loss (to create these vortices) is what we know as induced drag, and increases with Coefficient of lift. This means that induced drag is increased when: weight is increased (more weight = more lift required = higher lift coefficient). indicated airspeed, IAS, is decreased (less airflow means we need each particle of air to bend more, so higher lift coefficient - or just look at the lift equation, if speed reduces, something has to increase for the same lift to be made). Anything else causes an increased angle of attack (as angle of attack is directly proportional to coefficient of lift up until the stall). Therefore, given the possible options, the only correct one is "aircraft weight". Note: changing altitude does not affect induced drag in this question as we are flying at a constant IAS, which means that the same amount of air particles are flowing over the wing, no matter the altitude we are at, and compressibility effects are to be ignored.

content.question: On a non-precision approach with the autopilot engaged maintaining track and rate of descent, the wind changes from approximately 30 kt crosswind to 30 kt headwind. What action needs to be taken to maintain the correct vertical profile?

options.A: CAS must be decreased to compensate for the lower groundspeed.
options.B: Rate of descent shall be increased to compensate for the higher groundspeed.
options.C: Flap settings should be increased to increase rate of descent.
options.D: Rate of descent shall be decreased to compensate for the lower groundspeed.

key_points: With a change in the wind on the approach like this, there will be some ballooning effect to deal with if it is being hand-flown, but with the autopilot engaged, the rate of descent will be maintained quite closely, so this is not something that needs to be considered
The next change is that of the groundspeed

On the approach, a constant IAS/CAS is flown, so any increase in headwind decreases the groundspeed, and therefore, the aircraft will have to change it's rate of descent to maintain the same approach angle (usually 3º)
learning.explanation: With a change in the wind on the approach like this, there will be some ballooning effect to deal with if it is being hand-flown, but with the autopilot engaged, the rate of descent will be maintained quite closely, so this is not something that needs to be considered. The next change is that of the groundspeed. On the approach, a constant IAS/CAS is flown, so any increase in headwind decreases the groundspeed, and therefore, the aircraft will have to change it's rate of descent to maintain the same approach angle (usually 3º). If the aircraft did not change rate of descent, it will descend at the same amount of feet per minute, but take longer than expected to reach the Runway, so would get low on profile. The rate of descent on an approach is directly proportional to the groundspeed (for a 3º glidepath, the rate of descent [ft/min] is the GS [kt] x 5), and therefore a reduction in groundspeed requires a reduction in the rate of descent.

content.question: You are descending at a constant TAS and deploy the flaps. What will happen to your ROD (rate of descent) and your descent gradient?

options.A: Increase/decrease
options.B: Increase/increase
options.C: Decrease/increase
options.D: Decrease/decrease

key_points: When we add flaps, we increase our wing's coefficient of lift, and also its coefficient of drag (and sometimes wing area, depending on the flaps)

The increase in drag from flaps is always more than the increase in lift, as a wing has its best lift/drag ratio when clean (no flaps), this is the point we want to fly at when gliding for range, as it gives us the shallowest descent gradient and furthest glide distance

Note that the increase in lift is not actually useful in this question, as it only allows us to fly slower without stalling, but this question mentions that we are at a constant TAS, so that doesn't matter
learning.explanation: When we add flaps, we increase our wing's coefficient of lift, and also its coefficient of drag (and sometimes wing area, depending on the flaps). The increase in drag from flaps is always more than the increase in lift, as a wing has its best lift/drag ratio when clean (no flaps), this is the point we want to fly at when gliding for range, as it gives us the shallowest descent gradient and furthest glide distance. Note that the increase in lift is not actually useful in this question, as it only allows us to fly slower without stalling, but this question mentions that we are at a constant TAS, so that doesn't matter. The increased drag from flaps increases our gradient of descent in accordance with the following formula. Gradient of Descent (%) = [(D - T) / W] x 100 As we are maintaining a constant TAS (True Airspeed), then the Rate of Descent increases also, due to the following formula. ROD (ft/m) = TAS x Gradient of Descent Note: we are not taking into account any wind in these calculations, therefore the gradients of descent are "still air" gradients, but wind would not change the answers at all.

learning.explanation: AIR DENSITY As air density decreases (altitude and/or temperature increases), both engine and aerodynamic performance decrease. Aircraft performance depends on air density, which directly affects lift and drag, engine power, and propeller efficiency. To achieve this higher speed with the same engine power, a longer take-off run will be needed.

content.question: A jet aeroplane is flying at the speed for maximum range, below the optimum altitude. How does the specific range change when altitude increases? The specific range…

options.A: increases only if there is no wind.
options.B: first increases then decreases.
options.C: decreases.
options.D: does not change.

key_points: Optimum Altitude It is defined as being the pressure altitude which provides the greatest specific range or fuel mileage at a given weight and speed
Flying higher or lower than the optimum altitude will decrease the range of the airplane
It is important to understand that the optimum altitude is not fixed
learning.explanation: Optimum Altitude It is defined as being the pressure altitude which provides the greatest specific range or fuel mileage at a given weight and speed. Flying higher or lower than the optimum altitude will decrease the range of the airplane. It is important to understand that the optimum altitude is not fixed. As the weight decreases through fuel burn, the drag curve moves down and left. Therefore, the best range speed, 1.32VMD, falls and the total drag decreases. With decreasing weight, the airplane needs to slow down to maintain the best range speed. As it does so, the Mach number will also decrease meaning that the airplane is not limited by the high Mach number and corresponding high drag. This fact allows the airplane to climb a little. As the airplane climbs, the Mach number will increase again to its previous limiting value and drag will increase back to its previous value. But more importantly the higher altitude has decreased the specific fuel consumption. This means that over time, as the weight decreases with fuel burn, the optimum altitude increases. SPECIFIC RANGE (SR) = TAS ÷ FUEL FLOW Reaching the optimum level, the aircraft specific range increases. As the aircraft mass decreases due to fuel consumption the optimum level will be higher. If the aircraft does not climb to the new optimum altitude the specific range decreases.

Choose the combination of correct statements regarding the Accelerate-Stopping Distance Available (ASDA):

key_points: ASDA Distance from the start of the take-off run to the nearest point in the direction of take-off at which the aircraft cannot roll over the surface and be brought to rest in case of an aborted take-off without risk of accident
ASDA consists of TORA plus the stopway if available
The ASDA is the Accelerate-Stopping Distance available, for use in case of a Rejected Take-Off (RTO)
learning.explanation: ASDA Distance from the start of the take-off run to the nearest point in the direction of take-off at which the aircraft cannot roll over the surface and be brought to rest in case of an aborted take-off without risk of accident. ASDA consists of TORA plus the stopway if available. The ASDA is the Accelerate-Stopping Distance available, for use in case of a Rejected Take-Off (RTO). The majority of the statements in this question are quite simple, the ASDA includes the TORA (Take-Off Run Available), and the stopway for the take-off runway, but not the clearway. The other two statements are a little more complex. A starter extension is where a displaced threshold exists, and an aircraft can begin the take-off roll before the threshold of the runway. Therefore, any starter extension is part of the take-off run, and is included in the ASDA. However, the opposite runway stopway (if present) is not automatically considered a starter extension for the take-off runway, so is not included. content.question: The Specific Fuel Consumption (SFC) for a propeller engine is…

options.A: Fuel flow per unit of thrust.
options.B: The NM flown per kg of fuel.
options.C: Fuel flow per unit of power.
options.D: Aeroplane drag multiplied by TAS.

key_points: The overall fuel efficiency of a jet engine is usually expressed in terms of its Specific Fuel Consumption (SFC) and its propulsive and thermal efficiencies
The overall fuel efficiency of a piston engine is measured by its Specific Fuel Consumption (SFC) only
SFC is the mass of fuel required to produce a given amount of power/thrust for a given period of time
learning.explanation: The overall fuel efficiency of a jet engine is usually expressed in terms of its Specific Fuel Consumption (SFC) and its propulsive and thermal efficiencies. The overall fuel efficiency of a piston engine is measured by its Specific Fuel Consumption (SFC) only. SFC is the mass of fuel required to produce a given amount of power/thrust for a given period of time. The Specific Fuel Consumption (SFC) formulae are: For a propeller aircraft: SFC = Fuel Flow / Power. For a jet aircraft: SFC = Fuel Flow / Thrust. So, for a propeller aircraft, Fuel Flow = SFC x Power, which means that for a given SFC the fuel flow is proportional to the power required. Thus, the lower the SFC, the better the efficiency.

content.question: The maximum endurance speed is the equivalent of the...

options.B: maximum speed in autorotation.
options.C: best rate of climb speed (VY).
options.D: best range speed (VMR).

learning.explanation: VX is the speed at which an aeroplane achieves its maximum angle or gradient of climb. Since angle of climb depends on excess thrust, VX is the speed at which the difference between thrust available and drag is greatest. Because thrust available against speed is different for turbojet and propeller aeroplanes, it must be established at what speed VX is for both types of aeroplanes. For best angle of climb we need maximum excess thrust. If thrust were constant at all airspeeds, then at VMD where drag is minimum, the excess thrust and climb angle would be maximum. For maximum endurance we must fly at the speed at which fuel flow is minimum. Rate of climb is maximum when excess power is maximum. This occurs at approximately VMP. In prop aircraft fuel flow is proportional to power, so minimum fuel flow occurs at the speed at which power required is minimum. This speed is VMP. Rate of climb is equal to excess power divided by aircraft weight.

options.B: (1) up and right; (2) down and right

key_points: Power required is the power needed at any given speed to overcome the particular amount of drag that exists at that speed and Power available is the rate of application of thrust at a given speed

Both powers are given by the formulae: Power available = Thrust x Speed (TAS) Power required = Thrust Required x Speed (TAS) The aircraft flying at constant lift, resulting from constant Indicated Airspeed and angle of attack, will essentially fly at a higher True Airspeed at a higher altitude, because the loss of air density must be compensated for by an increased speed of flight to maintain the required dynamic pressure on the wings
Thus, the power required increases with increasing altitude, moving the Power Required vs
learning.explanation: Power required is the power needed at any given speed to overcome the particular amount of drag that exists at that speed and Power available is the rate of application of thrust at a given speed. Both powers are given by the formulae: Power available = Thrust x Speed (TAS) Power required = Thrust Required x Speed (TAS) The aircraft flying at constant lift, resulting from constant Indicated Airspeed and angle of attack, will essentially fly at a higher True Airspeed at a higher altitude, because the loss of air density must be compensated for by an increased speed of flight to maintain the required dynamic pressure on the wings. Thus, the power required increases with increasing altitude, moving the Power Required vs. TAS up and right along the tangent to the origin. Thrust produced by an engine decreases with altitude, because of the decreasing air density, which does not allow the engine to burn as much fuel. Also, the True Airspeed will increase for a constant Indicated Airspeed, but at a lower rate than the thrust reduces. Thus, the power available will decrease with increasing altitude and the "Power availbale vs. TAS" curve will move down and right.

key_points: Minimum drag speed (VMD) is the speed at which induced and profile drag values are equal
It is also the speed that has the lowest total drag penalty, VMD = minimum drag speed Therefore, this speed also represents the best lift-drag ratio (best aerodynamic efficiency)
And because minimum aircraft drag requires minimum thrust (i
learning.explanation: Minimum drag speed (VMD) is the speed at which induced and profile drag values are equal. It is also the speed that has the lowest total drag penalty, VMD = minimum drag speed Therefore, this speed also represents the best lift-drag ratio (best aerodynamic efficiency). And because minimum aircraft drag requires minimum thrust (i.e., thrust = drag), and given that thrust is a product of engine power and fuel consumption is a function of engine power used, the aircraft thus has its lowest fuel consumption in terms of fuel used per hour. Hence it produces the maximum endurance flight time for a given quantity of fuel. In this case, to minimise fuel consumption, the pilot should maintain altitude, keep the aircraft clean and reduce the speed to VMD.

content.question: A jet powered aeroplane is flying at its cruising altitude and the outside air temperature increases. What will happen to the Specific Range (SR) and the Specific Fuel Consumption (SFC)?

options.A: SR increases, SFC decreases.
options.B: SR remains constant, SFC increases.
options.C: SR decreases, SFC increases.
options.D: SR remains constant, SFC decreases.

key_points: To start with, we can assume that the jet aircraft is flying for best range, and when the temperature decreases, the aircraft continues to fly for best range

The increase in temperature is bad for a jet engine's specific fuel consumption, as cold temperatures and high RPM operation are best for decreasing an engine's specific fuel consumption, so warmer air is not as efficient, which means that it burns more fuel per unit of thrust produced

Specific Range = TAS/Fuel Flow and Fuel Flow = SFC x Drag So as the aircraft's SFC has increased, and the Drag has remained the same (jets cruise at constant Mach numbers and when only the temperature changes, the IAS also remains constant), so Fuel Flow has increased
learning.explanation: To start with, we can assume that the jet aircraft is flying for best range, and when the temperature decreases, the aircraft continues to fly for best range. The increase in temperature is bad for a jet engine's specific fuel consumption, as cold temperatures and high RPM operation are best for decreasing an engine's specific fuel consumption, so warmer air is not as efficient, which means that it burns more fuel per unit of thrust produced. Specific Range = TAS/Fuel Flow and Fuel Flow = SFC x Drag So as the aircraft's SFC has increased, and the Drag has remained the same (jets cruise at constant Mach numbers and when only the temperature changes, the IAS also remains constant), so Fuel Flow has increased. Now we can also say that TAS will increase, as the density has decreased. That means that both the top of the Specific Range equation (TAS) has increased, and the bottom (Fuel Flow) has also increased. We do not have exact figures, so how can we work out what the overall effect is? We know from the integrated range tables in the flight planning CAP (697) that an increase in temperature causes a increase in fuel consumption over the distances involved in the table, meaning the effect on specific fuel consumption must be the greater effect, and warmer temperatures decrease specific range. Therefore the correct answer is "SR decreases, SFC increases."

content.question: Compared to a more forward position, a Centre of Gravity close to, but not beyond, the aft limit:

options.A: improves the longitudinal stability.
options.B: increases the stalling speed.
options.C: decreases the maximum range.
options.D: improves the maximum range.

key_points: The total mass of aircraft is said to be act through one point called the center of gravity
The total lift acts through a point called the center of pressure
In straight and level flight these forces are in balance
learning.explanation: The total mass of aircraft is said to be act through one point called the center of gravity. The total lift acts through a point called the center of pressure. In straight and level flight these forces are in balance. Putting the center of gravity forward of the center of pressure means the aircraft tends to have a pitch down attitude. This requires a balancing downforce from the tail plane. With this extra force from the tail plane, lift from the wings must be increased to balance the forces. More lift means more induced drag, which means higher fuel consumption consequently decreasing the maximum range. For an aft CG position, the opposite applies, lower fuel consumption and maximum range increases.

Using a standard force diagram for an aircraft in the climb gives the equations: (Thrust - Drag)/Weight = sin(angle of climb) Lift/Weight = cos(angle of climb) The first equation is the one to use, and 7% Notes: The force diagram image uses α (alpha) for the climb angle and we are using γ (gamma), either is fine to use, but α is often used for angle of attack so we avoid it for angle of climb. Assuming "Lift = Weight" is a bit of a stretch, yes, as lift does not equal weight in the climb, but it is what EASA want you to do, so they can give you more complex questions like this without you having to do too much maths. This allows us to use L/D ratio very easily, so works nicely, even if not fully correct. sin(γ) is a good approximation of the gradient for small angles, even though tan is technically the one to use, they are very close in the angles we usually climb at. content.question: Upon first contact with their destination aerodrome, the crew of a jet aeroplane is informed to expect a few holds due to high traffic. What can the crew do to increase their aircraft's maximum endurance?

options.A: Cruise with VMAX RANGE in order to increase the fuel mileage.
options.B: Climb to the optimum altitude in order to increase specific range.
options.C: Cruise with VMD in order to minimise fuel used per unit of time.
options.D: Request a continuous descent in order to reduce the thrust setting.

key_points: The pilot of an aircraft in this scenario knows that they are going to have to wait some time before landing, which usually means entering a holding pattern
In order to maximise the amount of fuel they have left at this point, the crew should slow down and fly the rest of the way at the best endurance speed
As they are only going to end up holding anyway, they might as well save some fuel in the cruise, and have to do less holding patterns later on
learning.explanation: The pilot of an aircraft in this scenario knows that they are going to have to wait some time before landing, which usually means entering a holding pattern. In order to maximise the amount of fuel they have left at this point, the crew should slow down and fly the rest of the way at the best endurance speed. As they are only going to end up holding anyway, they might as well save some fuel in the cruise, and have to do less holding patterns later on. This is assuming that they have already "joined the queue" at their destination airport, which is implied in the question. The best endurance speed in a jet aircraft is the speed at which the engines need to produce the least thrust, as thrust is directly proportional to fuel flow, and we want to make our fuel flow the lowest it can be. The speed of minimum thrust required is the speed of least drag (as thrust directly opposed drag). We called this VMD, for minimum drag speed, and it is the speed that aircraft fly in the holding pattern, and when it is time in the air that is most desirable, rather than distance gone. It occurs at the bottom of the "total drag" curve as shown in the annex above, where the combination of induced and parasite drag equals the lowest value. There is no point climbing up to the optimum altitude at this stage, as it is not an efficient use of fuel to climb just before descent. Also, that option is not correct because we do not care about maximum range now, only maximum endurance.

content.question: An aircraft has two certified landing flaps positions, 25° and 35°. If a pilot chooses 35° instead of 25°, the aircraft will have:

options.A: a reduced landing distance and degraded go around performance.
options.B: an increased landing distance and better go around performance.
options.C: an increased landing distance and degraded go around performance.
options.D: a reduced landing distance and better go around performance.

key_points: EFFECT OF FLAPS ON LANDING/TAKE-OFF RUN AND CLIMB GRADIENT The use of high life devices (Flaps) will have an impact on the take-off and Landing roll and climb gradient
For a given runway length and airplane weight, selecting a greater flap setting will increase the lift coefficient, which reduces the stalling speed
As a consequence, the take-off speeds are reduced (the same lift will be created at smaller air speed due to greater lift coefficient)
learning.explanation: EFFECT OF FLAPS ON LANDING/TAKE-OFF RUN AND CLIMB GRADIENT The use of high life devices (Flaps) will have an impact on the take-off and Landing roll and climb gradient. For a given runway length and airplane weight, selecting a greater flap setting will increase the lift coefficient, which reduces the stalling speed. As a consequence, the take-off speeds are reduced (the same lift will be created at smaller air speed due to greater lift coefficient). This will reduce the take-off run. Flap extension during landings provides several advantages by: producing greater lift and permitting lower landing speed; producing greater drag, permitting a steep descent angle without airspeed increase. => Reducing the length of the landing roll. The down side of the use of flaps is that it generates more parasite drag: We get our best angle of climb and, therefore, our best gradient where there is the biggest gap between the thrust available and thrust required. The parasite drag from the extended flap closes the gap and the climb angle and climb gradient will reduce => go around performance is deteriorated. Hence as soon as we can after take off we accelerate and retract the flap and climb clean.

For a propeller aircraft, maximum endurance (time aloft) occurs when the minimum power is used to maintain steady level flight
VMP is the minimum power required speed, thereby the speed of minimum fuel flow
learning.explanation: Minimum Power Speed (VMP) is the speed at which minimum power is required. For a propeller aircraft, maximum endurance (time aloft) occurs when the minimum power is used to maintain steady level flight. VMP is the minimum power required speed, thereby the speed of minimum fuel flow. As a result, any speed below or above VMP increases fuel consumption.

content.question: Other factors remaining constant, the effect an increase of altitude, in a standard atmosphere, has on the value of VX and VY in terms of TAS is:

options.A: Both will increase.
options.B: Both will remain the same.
options.C: Both will decrease.

key_points: VX best angle of climb speed
VY best ROC speed
VY is plotted on the Power v TAS curve and VY is where the greatest excess of power available over power required exists
learning.explanation: VX best angle of climb speed. VY best ROC speed. VY is plotted on the Power v TAS curve and VY is where the greatest excess of power available over power required exists. (Note that the power available lines for a jet and prop are different.) VX is normally derived from the excess of thrust over drag but it can be plotted on the power required curve. VX for a jet is where the tangent from the origin just touches the power required curve, this is VMD, which is VX for a jet. content.question: An Operator is considering Johannesburg international airport as a new cargo destination. options.C: The maximum landing mass would be the higher because the landing distances would decrease.

key_points: Aeroplane performance depends on a number of different variables, some of which cannot be influenced by the operator
These include environmental conditions such as aerodrome pressure and temperature
Air density directly affects aircraft performance in terms of both aerodynamic and engine performance
learning.explanation: Aeroplane performance depends on a number of different variables, some of which cannot be influenced by the operator. These include environmental conditions such as aerodrome pressure and temperature. Air density directly affects aircraft performance in terms of both aerodynamic and engine performance. As the density of the air increases (lower density altitude), aircraft performance increases. Conversely, as air density decreases (higher density altitude), aircraft performance decreases. Higher temperature means lower air density at any given pressure altitude, extending both the take-off run and distance and lowering the performance-limited take-off mass for that day.

content.question: What issues you may experience with the take-off, if you were to pick up a new aircraft from a factory in Europe on a cold day?

options.B: A low VR making an engine failure easier to handle.

key_points: VMCG is defined as the minimum speed, whilst on the ground, that directional control can be maintained, using only aerodynamic controls, with one engine inoperative (critical engine on two engine airplanes) and take-off power applied on the other engine(s)
VMCG is an indicated air speed, so theoretically it would not be affected by air density

However, if an engine failure occurs, the engine can produce more power in higher air density, which means that the yawing moment in higher air density will also be larger, and the force produced on the rudder is greater
learning.explanation: VMCG is defined as the minimum speed, whilst on the ground, that directional control can be maintained, using only aerodynamic controls, with one engine inoperative (critical engine on two engine airplanes) and take-off power applied on the other engine(s). VMCG is an indicated air speed, so theoretically it would not be affected by air density. However, if an engine failure occurs, the engine can produce more power in higher air density, which means that the yawing moment in higher air density will also be larger, and the force produced on the rudder is greater. The angle of attack of the rudder is limited by its maximum deflection, therefore a higher speed will be needed to create more counter-yawing force on the rudder and maintain the aircraft under control.

options.B: It is the actual flight path reduced by a safety margin.

key_points: The difference between the net and gross flight paths/performance is as follows: The gross performance is the average performance that a fleet of aircraft should achieve if maintained satisfactorily and flown in accordance with the techniques established during flight certification and subsequently described in the aircraft performance manual
Gross performance therefore defines a level of performance that any aircraft of the same type has a 50 percent chance of exceeding at any time
The net performance is the gross performance diminished to allow for various contingencies that cannot be accounted for operationally, e
learning.explanation: The difference between the net and gross flight paths/performance is as follows: The gross performance is the average performance that a fleet of aircraft should achieve if maintained satisfactorily and flown in accordance with the techniques established during flight certification and subsequently described in the aircraft performance manual. Gross performance therefore defines a level of performance that any aircraft of the same type has a 50 percent chance of exceeding at any time. The net performance is the gross performance diminished to allow for various contingencies that cannot be accounted for operationally, e.g., variations in piloting technique, temporarily below-average performance, etc. It is improbable that the net performancel flight path will not be achieved in operation, provided the aircraft is flown in accordance with the recommended techniques, i.e., power, attitude, and speed.

content.question: A pilot is flying at the speed for the best rate of climb. He decides to slow down to VMD. What will happen to the climb gradient at VMD?

options.A: It will increase.
options.B: It will decrease
options.C: It remains the same
options.D: It decreases initially, then increases

key_points: VX - Best Angle of Climb Speed The IAS at which the airplane generates the greatest amount of Excess Thrust (Thrust minus Drag) and is therefore capable of its steepest climb gradient, is called VX
For an airplane powered by jet engines, VX is the same IAS as VMD
VX for a propeller airplane is less than VMD and at low altitudes will be in the region of VMP due to the way power is produced by propeller aircraft
learning.explanation: VX - Best Angle of Climb Speed The IAS at which the airplane generates the greatest amount of Excess Thrust (Thrust minus Drag) and is therefore capable of its steepest climb gradient, is called VX. For an airplane powered by jet engines, VX is the same IAS as VMD. VX for a propeller airplane is less than VMD and at low altitudes will be in the region of VMP due to the way power is produced by propeller aircraft. This is also roughly the same speed as maximum endurance due to the minimum drag/power required. VY - Best Rate of Climb Speed The speed to gain more altitude with the least time (Greatest Rate of Climb). This speed is faster than VX as the rate of climb can be improved by speeding up the aircraft. Even though this means higher drag, this drag increase is overwhelmed by the speed increase, which means the aircraft is climbing up a shallower slope, but at a higher speed, so has an overall greater climb rate. It is roughly the same speed as that of maximum range. For a jet, this means it is higher than VMD (usually quoted as 1.32 VMD with maximum range), and for a prop aircraft, this speed should be around VMD. For this question, then, we have to assume that a jet aircraft is being flown, as in a propeller aircraft, VY is effectively the same speed as VMD in most cases, so they could not slow down to VMD If the pilot is flying at VY and slows down to VMD (which is VX), the climb gradient will increase, but the rate of climb will decrease (after the airspeed has stabilised at VX).

This means that lift will be vertical and drag horizontal

learning.explanation: In straight-and-level flight, the flight path and the relative airflow are horizontal. This means that lift will be vertical and drag horizontal. In unaccelerated, straight-and-level flight, the thrust pulling the aeroplane forward must equal the drag pulling the aeroplane backward. Similarly, if the aeroplane is to remain level and not enter a climb or descent, weight must be equal and opposite of the lift. In steady, straight-and-level flight: L = W, and T = D L : Lift, D: Drag, W: Weight Lift equation formula shows that; if we keep equation although speed decreases below VMD ( minimum drag speed ) we have to increase something in the right side of the formula. content.question: Consider a fixed-pitch propeller aeroplane at take-off. When the aeroplane accelerates during the take-off run phase, the blade angle of attack will (1) _____ and the thrust produced by the propeller will (2) _____.

options.A: (1) increase; (2) decrease
options.B: (1) increase; (2) increase
options.C: (1) decrease; (2) increase
options.D: (1) decrease; (2) decrease

key_points: Note: This should not really be a Performance question, as it is more closely related to Principles of Flight
Question 812798 is the PoF counterpart, but this question has been identified at least twice in Performance exams, so we have put it in both subjects
The figure shows the changes that take place as the aircraft speed (TAS) increases
learning.explanation: Note: This should not really be a Performance question, as it is more closely related to Principles of Flight. Question 812798 is the PoF counterpart, but this question has been identified at least twice in Performance exams, so we have put it in both subjects. The figure shows the changes that take place as the aircraft speed (TAS) increases. Assuming that propeller RPM and blade pitch angle remains constant, at a low speed the angle of attack will be large, giving a lot of thrust. Alpha will reduce with increasing speed and at about 4 degrees the blade will be operating at its best lift/drag ratio, i.e. the propeller is achieving its highest efficiency. Higher speeds (which can usually only be reached in a dive) will reduce the blade angle of attack to its zero lift value of about minus 4 degrees. At this point, the propeller will be producing zero thrust. The thrust that is produced by the propeller depends on the angle of attack of the blade. The angle of attack of the blade depends in turn on the airspeed and induced airflow through the propeller. At low airspeeds the angle of attack will be large, near the stall, and thrust will be at its maximum. As forward speed increases, the angle of attack decreases and thrust reduces. That means that the maximum thrust produced by a propeller driven aircraft, also occurs at zero forward airspeed and reduces with forward speed. A fixed propeller can only have one optimum combination of forward airspeed and engine RPM and only one optimum propeller efficiency. At all other combinations it operates less efficiently. This effect can be offset to an extent by using a variable pitch propeller, which can change the blade angle, coarsening the blade angle at higher speeds to maintain the optimum angle of attack.

content.question: Along with aeroplane mass, which other factors have an influence on the service ceiling?

options.A: Air temperature and the position of the CG.
options.B: Maximum differential pressure and winds.
options.C: Airspace capacity and clear air turbulence.
options.D: Winds and pressure.

key_points: SERVICE CEILING The service ceiling is the altitude at which the rate of climb reduces to a specified (continious) value

These values, which are intended to be practically achievable, are: 500 fpm for jet aeroplanes, and 100 fpm for propeller aeroplanes The climb limited mass is also known as a WAT limited mass (Weight, Altitude, and Temperature) or MAT limited mass (Mass, Altitude, and Temperature)
As we understood from the definition above; mass and the dissemination of the weight to the compartments of aircraft directly effects the service ceiling
learning.explanation: SERVICE CEILING The service ceiling is the altitude at which the rate of climb reduces to a specified (continious) value. These values, which are intended to be practically achievable, are: 500 fpm for jet aeroplanes, and 100 fpm for propeller aeroplanes The climb limited mass is also known as a WAT limited mass (Weight, Altitude, and Temperature) or MAT limited mass (Mass, Altitude, and Temperature). As we understood from the definition above; mass and the dissemination of the weight to the compartments of aircraft directly effects the service ceiling. FACTORS AFFECTING TAKE-OFF DISTANCE REQUIRED The take-off distance required (TODR) varies with aerodrome conditions, aeroplane mass, and aeroplane configuration. AEROPLANE MASS A heavier aeroplane accelerates more slowly and needs to achieve a faster take-off speed. This results in a longer take-off distance required. When the TODR equals the take-off distance available (TODA), the aeroplane is at its field limited take-off mass (FLTOM) for the given flap setting. AERODROME PRESSURE ALTITUDE The higher an aerodrome’s pressure altitude, the longer the TODR. This is because the air is less dense, which affects both the engine thrust and actual speed at rotation. The reduction in air density reduces the engine mass flow and, therefore, thrust, which results in slower acceleration. Second, the reduced air density results in a faster TAS for the same calibrated airspeed VR. TEMPERATURE Hotter temperatures result in lower air density. Again, this reduces the thrust and, therefore, acceleration of the aeroplane and necessitates a faster TAS for the same VR. WIND The head or tailwind component along the runway affects the ground speed of the aeroplane for the same rotate speed, VR, which is a CAS. A reducing headwind or increasing tailwind increases the actual ground speed, which equates to the same VR. Acceleration to a faster actual ground speed results in a longer take-off run and distance.

content.question: The pilot of an aircraft changes its heading to the right, from 214º to 334º and makes a rate-1 turn. The duration of this manoeuvre is:

options.A: impossible to calculate, because we need the aircraft's TAS.
options.B: 40 seconds.
options.C: 30 seconds.
options.D: impossible to calculate, because we need the aircraft's angle of bank.

key_points: If the turn is unbalanced, an aircraft either slips into, or skids out of the turn, thereby reducing the aerodynamic efficiency of the aircraft

To help correct for these unwanted conditions, the aircraft is flown using the balance part of the turn and balance indicator During a balanced turn the ball remains in the centre of the balance indicator and the pilot remains upright in the seat relative to the aircraft, with no tendency to lean
Rate of turn is the measurement of how long it takes for an aircraft to turn, measured in degrees per second
learning.explanation: If the turn is unbalanced, an aircraft either slips into, or skids out of the turn, thereby reducing the aerodynamic efficiency of the aircraft. To help correct for these unwanted conditions, the aircraft is flown using the balance part of the turn and balance indicator During a balanced turn the ball remains in the centre of the balance indicator and the pilot remains upright in the seat relative to the aircraft, with no tendency to lean. Rate of turn is the measurement of how long it takes for an aircraft to turn, measured in degrees per second. This is particularly important during instrument flying where rate-1 turns are usually carried out at a rate of 3° per second. This means that the aircraft turns through 180° in 1 minute, or 360° in 2 minutes. A steeper angle of bank is required to carry out a rate-1 turn at higher airspeeds. To solve this exercise, first we need to calculate how many degrees was the turn performed and then apply the rate of turn: 334º - 214º = 120º at 3º/second (rate-1 turn) 120/3º = 40 seconds Note: This question is out of the scope of performance, however a student has confirmed that it appeared in their performance exam.

content.question: On a reciprocating engine aeroplane, to maintain a given angle of attack, configuration and altitude at higher gross mass…

options.A: an increase in airspeed and power is required.
options.B: requires an increase in power and decrease in the airspeed.
options.C: an increase in airspeed is required but power setting does not change.
options.D: a higher coefficient of drag is required.

key_points: As the aircraft mass increases, the Lift required must increase, so as to maintain the altitude
So, the induced drag increases and, thus, the induced power required increases too
The parasite drag and as a result the parasite power required remain unchanged
learning.explanation: As the aircraft mass increases, the Lift required must increase, so as to maintain the altitude. So, the induced drag increases and, thus, the induced power required increases too. The parasite drag and as a result the parasite power required remain unchanged. Thus, the total power required curve, affected only by the increased induced power required, moves up and slightly right. Therefore, the total power required increases and the selected airspeed will increase as well as moves to the right. An alternative explanation comes throught the Lift formula: L = CL ½ rho V2 S. At a higher gross mass, the Lift required must be increased, to maintain the altitude. With CL (angle of attack) and S (configuration) constant, the airspeed, V, must be increased, so as to increase the Lift required and maintain the altitude constant. The power required is: DRAG x AIRSPEED. With increased Lift required, the induced drag increases and as a result the total drag increases, too. Therefore, with increased airspeed and drag, the power required increases, as well.

content.question:
Refer to figure.
Which of the figures shows the change in the total drag graph when density altitude is increased?

options.A: Figure 1
options.B: Figure 2
options.C: Figure 3
options.D: Figure 4

key_points: When density altitude increases, the air gets "thinner", meaning that there are less air particles per cubic metre, and therefore less air particles will hit our aircraft and flow over its wings per mile flown
This would decrease lift and drag if we were trying to maintain the same TAS
However, to counteract this effect, we fly our aircraft at a constant IAS/CAS (Indicated Airspeed/Calibrated Airspeed), which is a simple measure of dynamic pressure
learning.explanation: When density altitude increases, the air gets "thinner", meaning that there are less air particles per cubic metre, and therefore less air particles will hit our aircraft and flow over its wings per mile flown. This would decrease lift and drag if we were trying to maintain the same TAS. However, to counteract this effect, we fly our aircraft at a constant IAS/CAS (Indicated Airspeed/Calibrated Airspeed), which is a simple measure of dynamic pressure. This value measures the amount of air particles hitting the aircraft, and their speed. If we fly at a constant IAS, but climb higher in the atmosphere, the lower air density means that we have to fly faster to get the same amount of dynamic pressure, meaning the same amount of air particles over the wing, etc. This is an increase in TAS (True Airspeed) for a constant IAS. IAS directly controls our drag and our lift, as they vary proportionally to dynamic pressure, see the lift or drag equation for the mathematical proof here, it is very easy to spot. D = (1/2 x ρ x V2)x CD x S As dynamic pressure is 1/2 x ρ x V2, which is measured by the IAS, then drag is directly proportional to IAS, coefficient of drag, and surface area. If the graph was for total drag against IAS, then the curve would remain in exactly the same position with increased altitude (ignoring compressibility at very high altitudes). As the X-axis on the graphs is TAS, not IAS, then with an increase in altitude, the drag curve will look the same, but will be shifted to the right, due to the increased TAS for the same IAS at higher altitudes, but as the same forces of drag exist at each point on the curve, the curve will not move up or down. The answer is therefore figure 3, moving to the right.

Gross performance therefore defines a level of performance that any aircraft of the same type has a 50 percent chance of exceeding at any time

learning.explanation: The difference between the net and gross flight paths/performance is as follows: The gross performance is the average performance that a fleet of aircraft should achieve if maintained satisfactorily and flown in accordance with the techniques established during flight certification and subsequently described in the aircraft performance manual. Gross performance therefore defines a level of performance that any aircraft of the same type has a 50 percent chance of exceeding at any time. The net performance is the gross performance diminished to allow for various contingencies that cannot be accounted for operationally, e.g., variations in piloting technique, temporarily below-average performance, etc. It is improbable that the net performancel flight path will not be achieved in operation, provided the aircraft is flown in accordance with the recommended techniques, i.e., power, attitude, and speed. The net take-off flight path (NTOFP) is the gross take-off flight path minus a safety margin, i.e. reduced by a fixed percentage depending on the number of engines the aircraft has or the aircraft category (A or B) and must clear all obstacles by at least 35 ft (class A).

content.question: Which of the following statements is correct in relation to a turbojet engine’s Specific Fuel Consumption (SFC)?

options.A: Temperature has NO effect on SFC.
options.B: SFC decreases at lower altitudes and warmer ambient temperatures.
options.C: SFC decreases at higher altitudes and colder ambient temperatures.
options.D: Altitude has NO effect on SFC.

key_points: SPECIFIC FUEL CONSUMPTION Specific fuel consumption (SFC) in a jet is the fuel flow per unit of thrust, while SFC for a propeller is the fuel flow per unit of power
It is a measurement of efficiency, lower SFC means less fuel used, so is better
It is also an engine measurement, not to do with the aircraft's aerodynamics
learning.explanation: SPECIFIC FUEL CONSUMPTION Specific fuel consumption (SFC) in a jet is the fuel flow per unit of thrust, while SFC for a propeller is the fuel flow per unit of power. It is a measurement of efficiency, lower SFC means less fuel used, so is better. It is also an engine measurement, not to do with the aircraft's aerodynamics. In a turbojet engine, SFC is lowest (which is best) when the air temperature is low, and also when the engine is running at its design RPM of approximately 90 to 95% rpm. This means that SFC is proportional to temperature. It also means that the engine-aircraft combination is most efficient at high altitude where the thrust required to overcome drag is approximately 90 to 95% of the thrust available. This creates an optimum altitude for a turbojet engine where the most efficient engine speed lines up with the most efficient airframe speed. This is an aerodynamic consideration though, and is not actually about the SFC This then gets a little complex, as SFC, (being engine dictated, not aerodynamic) is not actually to do with the pressure of the air (pressure altitude), but actually changes based on the temperature of the air, colder air being more efficient to burn, therefore lower SFC. The problem with this is that the pressure altitude usually dictates the temperature, higher altitude = colder temperatures = lower SFC. This means that we are going to have to discount the answer that states, "Altitude has NO effect on SFC.", because it does affect it, just via the changing temperatures. The answer doesn't leave any "wiggle room" to argue its case, so we cannot declare it true. Therefore we have to choose the answer stating, "SFC decreases at higher altitudes and cold ambient temperatures.", because this effectively goes through our own thought process of working out SFC, higher altitude = colder temperature = lower SFC. Note: any further exam feedback on this question can be put in the comments or sent to info@atplquestions.com. Thank You.

options.B: Remains constant in the tropopause.
options.C: Decreases in the tropopause.
options.D: Increases in the tropopause.

key_points: Variation of TAS with Altitude at a Constant Mach Number Mach Number = TAS / LSS Therefore, TAS = Mach no
x LSS As altitude increases the temperature drop, local speed of sound decreases and TAS decreases up to the tropopause and then remain constant
As altitude decreases the temperature will rise, local speed of sound will increase and TAS will increase
learning.explanation: Variation of TAS with Altitude at a Constant Mach Number Mach Number = TAS / LSS Therefore, TAS = Mach no. x LSS As altitude increases the temperature drop, local speed of sound decreases and TAS decreases up to the tropopause and then remain constant. As altitude decreases the temperature will rise, local speed of sound will increase and TAS will increase. Above the tropopause the temperature will remain constant, therefore the local speed of sound remains constant. Climbing or descending above the tropopause at a constant Mach no., the TAS will remain constant.

You probably noticed that in hot days your airplane not well-performing
That's because with hot temperatures, density altitude increases and your airplane "feels" like it's flying at a higher altitude
learning.explanation: Density Altitude Density altitude is pressure altitude corrected for non-standard temperature. You probably noticed that in hot days your airplane not well-performing. That's because with hot temperatures, density altitude increases and your airplane "feels" like it's flying at a higher altitude. Less air mass flowing over your wings prevents you from generate as much lift, and less oxygen mass in your cylinders prevents you from burning as much fuel, meaning less power. Decreasing air density decreases performance, so be careful on hot days at high altitudes.

content.question:
What is the all-engines climb gradient for a twin-engine aeroplane with the following data given?
Thrust per engine: 33000 lbs
Mass: 89500 kg
Lift to Drag ratio: 7.8:1
g = 10 m/s2

key_points: "The weight of an object is equal to its mass multiplied by the acceleration of gravity
" So, Weight = Mass x g = 89500 kg x 10 m/s2 = 895000 N

Also, the climb angles are very small, so, for the majority of such questions, we assume that: Weight = Lift = 895000 N (despite the fact that it's slightly more) and that Sin Climb angle = Tan Climb angle
learning.explanation: "The weight of an object is equal to its mass multiplied by the acceleration of gravity." So, Weight = Mass x g = 89500 kg x 10 m/s2 = 895000 N. Also, the climb angles are very small, so, for the majority of such questions, we assume that: Weight = Lift = 895000 N (despite the fact that it's slightly more) and that Sin Climb angle = Tan Climb angle. With a Lift to Drag ratio of 7.8:1, the Drag is: 895000/7.8 = 114743.6 N Since the Thrust per engine is 33000 lbs or 33000 lbs / 2.2 = 15000 kg, then the Total thrust produced by both engines will be: 15000 kg x 10 m/s2 x 2 = 300000 N. We also know that: Sin Climb angle = (Thrust - Drag) / Weight = (300000 N - 114743.6 N) / 895000 N = 0.207 Thus, the climb gradient expressed in percentage will be: Climb Gradient (%) = Tan Climb angle x 100 = Sin Climb angle x 100 = 0.207 X 100 = 20.7%.

content.question: Consider the curve for the thrust required versus speed, for a jet aeroplane. What speed can be obtained from the minimum of this curve? The speed for:

options.B: Max Endurance, because fuel flow is proportional to thrust at the minimum.
options.C: Max Endurance, because fuel flow is proportional to power required.
options.D: Max Range, because this speed corresponds to the maximum lift to drag ratio at the minimum.

key_points: Note that the wording of the correct answer could be confusing

The fuel flow of a jet engine is approximately proportional to thrust output throughout the whole operating range (not just at this minimum thrust required point - remember that the engine doesn't know you are flying at VMD, that is an airframe consideration)
This assumption works fine for the exams, but in reality there are other factors at play that skew the graphs a little
learning.explanation: Note that the wording of the correct answer could be confusing. The fuel flow of a jet engine is approximately proportional to thrust output throughout the whole operating range (not just at this minimum thrust required point - remember that the engine doesn't know you are flying at VMD, that is an airframe consideration). This assumption works fine for the exams, but in reality there are other factors at play that skew the graphs a little. Jet Aircraft Endurance Maximum endurance will occur at minimum fuel flow. In a jet aircraft means minimum thrust and therefore minimum drag, VMD. Propeller Aircraft Endurance Minimum fuel flow for a propeller aircraft occurs when power required is minimum, so the speed to fly for endurance is VMP. VMP is minimum power to maintain straight and level flight, always less than VMD therefore the speed is unstable. Jet Aircraft Range The greatest still air range will occur when we get the largest TAS for the smallest thrust required, the best TAS/DRAG ratio. This point lies at the tangent of the drag curve (from the origin), 1.32VMD. Propeller Aircraft Range The greatest still air range will occur when we get the largest TAS for the smallest power required (not thrust). This point lies at the tangent of the power curve, VMD. Jet Propeller Best Range Speed 1.32 VMD VMD Best Endurance Speed VMD VMP

key_points: Maximum Endurance is the maximum time that an aircraft can remain airborne
The lowest Specific Fuel Consumption (SFC) for a piston aircraft is when the intake pressure is high, RPM low and the throttle wide open, which means that SFC is at its lowest at about Sea Level
Also, SFC = Fuel Flow / Power, which means that for a given SFC, the fuel flow is proportional to the power required, which is DRAG x TAS
learning.explanation: Maximum Endurance is the maximum time that an aircraft can remain airborne. The lowest Specific Fuel Consumption (SFC) for a piston aircraft is when the intake pressure is high, RPM low and the throttle wide open, which means that SFC is at its lowest at about Sea Level. Also, SFC = Fuel Flow / Power, which means that for a given SFC, the fuel flow is proportional to the power required, which is DRAG x TAS. With decreasing altitude, TAS also decreases, so power required decreases too. Therefore, as SFC and Power required decreases with decreasing altitude, then the Fuel Flow decreases too. The lowest SFC permits to remain airborne as much as possible, giving the maximum endurance.

content.question: A turbojet is flying at a constant IAS and pressure altitude. Given that a ± 1° of ISA deviation results in a change in fuel flow of ± 0.2%, determine how much the specific fuel consumption would change if the OAT is ISA +10°C rather than ISA:

options.A: 2% increase in SFC.
options.B: 2% decrease in SFC.
options.C: 20% increase in SFC.
options.D: 20% decrease in SFC.

key_points: Specific Fuel Consumption (SFC) is the amount of fuel used per unit of thrust (for jets) and unit of power (for props) in one unit of time
SFC varies with the ambient conditions
SFC is best at a minimum and one of the factors it is dependent upon include: Temperature
learning.explanation: Specific Fuel Consumption (SFC) is the amount of fuel used per unit of thrust (for jets) and unit of power (for props) in one unit of time. SFC varies with the ambient conditions. SFC is best at a minimum and one of the factors it is dependent upon include: Temperature. In cold air, at a particular altitude, the RPM may be reduced to provide the power required because: (a) The power available from the engine is greater. (b) The power required to propel the airframe in cold air is less. The colder the temperature, therefore, the lower will be the SFC because the power absorbed (wasted) at the lower temperature is reduced and the thermal efficiency is increased. As temperature increases, the air becomes less dense. Consequently, engine efficiency decreases and SFC increases. If 1º on ISA gives +0.2% fuel flow increase per unit of thrust, 10º will give an increase of 2%.

content.question: Which of the following factors will lead to an increase of ground distance during a glide, while maintaining the appropriate minimum glide angle speed?

options.A: Headwind.
options.B: Decrease of aircraft mass.
options.C: Increase of aircraft mass.
options.D: Tailwind.

key_points: The best glide angle occurs at VMD, flying at this speed will give the best range in a glide

Glide angle (and glide range) itself is independent of aircraft mass - provided the aircraft glides at VMD, since it is the lift over drag (L/D) ratio that determines the gliding range and it is unchanged with mass
However, a Speed faster or slower than VMD will lead to steeper glide angles
learning.explanation: The best glide angle occurs at VMD, flying at this speed will give the best range in a glide. Glide angle (and glide range) itself is independent of aircraft mass - provided the aircraft glides at VMD, since it is the lift over drag (L/D) ratio that determines the gliding range and it is unchanged with mass. However, a Speed faster or slower than VMD will lead to steeper glide angles. Glide angle = CD / CL GLIDING DISTANCE Wind speed is an important practical influence on gliding distance over the surface. With a tailwind, the glide distance achieved will be increased as a result of the increased groundspeed. Whereas with a headwind, it will be reduced because of the consequently slower groundspeed. GLIDING TIME The aircraft's mass varies the time the aircraft will glide for. The heavier the aircraft is, the higher the airspeed must be to obtain the same glide ratio (higher VMD). If two aircraft have the same L/D ratio but different weights and start a glide from the same altitude, the heavier aircraft gliding at a higher airspeed will arrive at the same touchdown point in a shorter time. However, both aircraft will cover the same distance but the lighter one will take a longer time to do so. SUMMARY: Glide Distance (Varies with wind) => Tailwind increases glide distance => Headwind decreases glide distance Glide Duration (Varies with mass) => Low mass increases glide duration => High mass decreases glide duration

content.question: Delays are expected at the arrival aerodrome at which a jet transport aeroplane plans to land. By managing the en-route airspeed, the pilot can increase the flight endurance by flying at…

options.A: minimum drag speed (VMD) at an intermediate flap configuration, due to the lower VMD speed value.
options.B: Long Range Cruise speed (LRC), at clean configuration, which corresponds to the minimum required total thrust.
options.C: Long Range Cruise speed (LRC), at an intermediate flap configuration, due to the lower LRC speed value.
options.D: minimum drag speed (VMD) at clean configuration, which corresponds to the minimum required total thrust.

key_points: In order to maintain best endurance speed in a jet aircraft, we want to use as little thrust as possible (for the lowest fuel burn), whilst maintaining the same amount of lift
This means we have to reduce Drag (the opposing force of Thrust) to its minimal possible value
This means flying at the speed which corresponds to minimum drag, VMD
learning.explanation: In order to maintain best endurance speed in a jet aircraft, we want to use as little thrust as possible (for the lowest fuel burn), whilst maintaining the same amount of lift. This means we have to reduce Drag (the opposing force of Thrust) to its minimal possible value. This means flying at the speed which corresponds to minimum drag, VMD. In a jet aircraft, VMD gives us the Best Endurance and Best Angle of Climb (VX). When flaps are put down, this does not affect our induced drag, as our lift value remains the same (equal to our weight). It does increase our parasite drag though, by presenting a larger surface to the airflow, and therefore increases our overall drag. This means that more thrust is required with flaps out, and therefore we will burn fuel faster, as well as flying slower, due to lower VMD speed in a “dirty” configuration. This means that Best Endurance occurs at VMD in the clean configuration.

content.question: A piece of luggage was meant to be placed in the rear hold of a light twin aircraft, but was mistakenly placed in the forward hold. Which of the following is true for take-off?

options.A: The aircraft may suffer from excessive yaw on the ground.
options.B: The aircraft is more tail heavy and will have improved climb.
options.C: The aircraft will be more nose heavy and will have reduced climb performance.
options.D: The luggage will have the same effect on the take-off in either hold compartment.

key_points: The luggage being placed in the forward hold, instead of where it was supposed to be placed (the aft hold) means that the aircraft's CG is actually further forward than the pilots are aware of
The location of an aircraft's CG is an important factor for many things, both for stability and control as well as for the aircraft's performance

When the CG of an aircraft is further forward, the aircraft will be more nose heavy, and to counteract this, the tailplane provides a downforce on the tail in order to keep the nose of the aircraft up
learning.explanation: The luggage being placed in the forward hold, instead of where it was supposed to be placed (the aft hold) means that the aircraft's CG is actually further forward than the pilots are aware of. The location of an aircraft's CG is an important factor for many things, both for stability and control as well as for the aircraft's performance. When the CG of an aircraft is further forward, the aircraft will be more nose heavy, and to counteract this, the tailplane provides a downforce on the tail in order to keep the nose of the aircraft up. This downforce directly opposes what the main wing is doing, producing lift. Therefore, the greater the downforce, the greater the lift that the main wing needs to produce. For every bit of lift the wing produces though, there is some induced drag that occurs, which means that further forward CG locations cause higher drag, and therefore lower climb performance, shorter aircraft range, and generally worse efficiency.

key_points: EFFECT OF FLAPS ON LANDING/TAKE-OFF RUN AND CLIMB GRADIENT The use of high life devices (Flaps) will have an impact on the take-off and Landing roll and climb gradient
For a given runway length and airplane weight, selecting a greater flap setting will increase the lift coefficient, which reduces the stalling speed
As a consequence, the take-off speeds are reduced (the same lift will be created at smaller air speed due to greater lift coefficient)
learning.explanation: EFFECT OF FLAPS ON LANDING/TAKE-OFF RUN AND CLIMB GRADIENT The use of high life devices (Flaps) will have an impact on the take-off and Landing roll and climb gradient. For a given runway length and airplane weight, selecting a greater flap setting will increase the lift coefficient, which reduces the stalling speed. As a consequence, the take-off speeds are reduced (the same lift will be created at smaller air speed due to greater lift coefficient). This will reduce the take-off run. Flap extension during landings provides several advantages by: producing greater lift and permitting lower landing speed; producing greater drag, permitting a steep descent angle without airspeed increase. => Reducing the length of the landing roll. The down side of the use of flaps is that it generates more parasite drag: We get our best angle of climb and, therefore, our best gradient where there is the biggest gap between the thrust available and thrust required. The parasite drag from the extended flap closes the gap and the climb angle and climb gradient will reduce => go around performance is deteriorated. Hence as soon as we can after take off we accelerate and retract the flap and climb clean. => With flaps down, Rate of Climb should be lower compared to clean configuration. The only graph depicting such scenario is "a".

content.question: If all other factors remain constant, how does flaps and slats retraction affect VX and VY of an aeroplane?

options.B: Both decrease.

learning.explanation: 032.01.04.01.09: Explain the effect of configuration on climb performance (angle and rate of climb, and Vx and Vy). Effect of configuration on VX The aircraft configuration is a determining factor that influences the maximum climb angle. In the first image provided, a climb with flaps (or gear) extended is illustrated and compared to the clean configuration. The first figure depicts an increase in parasite area which results in a higher parasite drag. Consequently, the total drag curve shifts upwards and to the left. The thrust required also increases, leading to a slower IAS for VX. As the necessary thrust has increased, the excess thrust decreases, which in turn causes a decrease in maximum climb gradient. Ultimately, flaps or gear usage reduces both maximum climb gradient and VX. Therefore, in this case, the retraction of flaps/slats will result in an increase in VX. Effect of configuration on VY The power required curves will undergo a similar shift as the drag curve. The second figure depicts a decrease in the available excess power, which is indicated by the blue double-headed arrows. As you may remember, a decrease in excess power leads to a reduction in the rate of climb. Nonetheless, the critical point to note is that the speed for maximum excess power is no longer the same when the gear and/or flaps are extended. Instead, it becomes lower. As a result, the climb rate and VY are reduced with the gear and/or flaps extended. Therefore, in this case, the retraction of flaps/slats will result in an increase in VY.

Recent feedback has confirmed the correct option to be VMD. The correct option in the initial feedback was VMO. Please let us know in the comments if you see this question in an exam, and any information you have about it, as our feedback may not be complete. Alternatively, feedback can be sent to info@atplquestions.com, thank you. There is also a very similar question in POF, but we are not sure of the validity of the limited feedback for that question. In the event of a fuel leak, our main problem as a flight crew is the chance of fuel exhaustion before a safe landing has been made. It is for that reason that we must make our way to the nearest suitable airfield as fast as possible, but by using the least amount of fuel; after all, we do not want to run out of fuel faster than we have to, by using it or by leaking it. It is for this reason that we have to fly at the best range speed, the same as we would when we want to reach a destination whilst using as little fuel as possible. However, this is a different "best range" speed. When we are leaking out fuel, our total fuel "consumption" changes, and goes from the standard fuel consumption/speed curve (which closely follows the drag curve), to the same curve, just lifted up, as the fuel consumption has been increased across the board by whatever rate the fuel is leaking at. Of course, the leak could be variable with speed or pressure, etc. but this is the general idea of it, and we should not have to delve as far as those factors. The best range of an aircraft is the point at which the fuel consumption is lowest for the highest speed, and this is shown on the graph by the point where a line from the origin first touches the curve. As you can see in the annex above, the best range speed is higher for the curve with the fuel leak. This is because the fuel is also leaking from the tank, and the faster we go, the less we allow to leak from the tank overall, so the more we have available to burn. This finds an equilibrium with how much drag we are willing to accept by flying faster, and therefore burning fuel at a higher rate. The faster the fuel leak, the higher this optimal speed becomes, starting at the normal "Best Range" speed for a very small/no leak, and increasing to VMO for incredibly fast fuel leaks. Further note: We would prefer an answer that mentions something to do with the increased best range speed, or perhaps a speed between best range speed (or LRC) and VMO. Important note: The current feedback is conflicting between exam authorities about which answer is correct. Some say that VMO is correct, and some say VMD is the correct option, please let us know what you get in you exam, and if any appeal process you might decide to take is successful or not.

learning.explanation: This is a long question but is actually very simple. The power to weight ratio of an aircraft is simply its power output divided by its gross weight (current weight). For an aircraft to have a higher power to weight ratio, it either needs higher power output, or lower weight. In the event that the twin engined aircraft has an engine failure, it now has the same power output as the single engine (160 hp), and the only thing dictating the power to weight ratios is the relative weights of the two aircraft.
