learning.explanation: IMPORTANT NOTE: We believe this question to be very flawed, and that there are no truly correct options. All recent feedback points to “actual flight performance with NO safety factor” as being correct in the exam, but as per our explanation below, the gross performance is not the actual flight performance, instead it is the expected average fleet performance. It is possible that some authorities have picked up on this being incorrect, so look out for the “fixed” question, being present in your real exam, which would have a correct answer of “calculated performance with NO safety factor”, or something with that meaning. Please let us know in the comments if you see any version of this question in your real exam, and what you can remember from it, thank you! When aircraft are being certified, the manufacturer must test the aircraft in many different ways to define certain levels of performance for many phases of flight, such as take-off distance, maximum rate of climb, landing distance and many more. There are different types of performance categorisation. Measured Performance is the performance achieved by the manufacturer under test conditions for certification. It utilises new aeroplanes and the test pilots, and is therefore not representative of the actual performance that any single aircraft might be able to achieve in normal circumstances, flown by a normal pilot. Gross Performance is the expected fleet average of aeroplanes, given that they are sufficiently maintained and flown as per the techniques detailed in the flight manuals, by a normal pilot. This means that any aircraft in the fleet has a 50% chance of exceeding this performance, but also a 50% chance of not meeting this performance. Net Performance is the gross performance, reduced by the safety margin, to account for various possibilities that could commonly cause reduced performance, such as variations in pilot technique, below-average aircraft performance, etc. The safety margin is set so that the chance of an aircraft not meeting the net performance level is extremely low. The safety margin is not fixed, It depends on the likelihood of the situation occurring, and is set to make sure that the total probability of an incident or accident occurring is at least lower than 1 in 1 million, when a passenger buys their ticket (known as their “remote probability”). This might mean that the safety margin (between gross and net performance) is large for likely events such as a take-off with all engines operating, but the safety margin is very low or even zero for unlikely events such as an engine failure at V1.

content.question: Complete the following statement, the best climb performance is obtained with a (1) _____ outside air temperature and a (2) _____ pressure altitude.

options.A: (1) low; (2) high
options.B: (1) low; (2) low
options.C: (1) high; (2) high
options.D: (1) high; (2) low

key_points: There are two different ways to measure the climb performance, the angle of climb and the rate of climb
To get the maximum of either requires the same principle, just with slightly different criteria
In short, we need more thrust than drag, and the amount of "excess thrust" decides how quickly we can climb, as this excess energy has to be converted into gravitational potential
learning.explanation: There are two different ways to measure the climb performance, the angle of climb and the rate of climb. To get the maximum of either requires the same principle, just with slightly different criteria. In short, we need more thrust than drag, and the amount of "excess thrust" decides how quickly we can climb, as this excess energy has to be converted into gravitational potential. The amount of excess thrust (divided by the mass of the aircraft) decides the angle of climb. The airspeed then decides how quickly we fly up that angle, the rate of climb. Between VX and VY (Best angle and best rate of climb, respectively), the excess thrust (therefore angle of climb) decreases, but the airspeed increases significantly moreso, so we travel up a lower angle, but at a much higher speed, gaining altitude quicker (see annex above). To gain the most "excess thrust", which is just thrust minus drag, we should fly at the lowest drag speed (which is an IAS, so does not change with altitude), and produce the most thrust possible. Therefore, to get the best climb performance, we just need to increase thrust. The highest thrust possible from any engine (jet or propeller) is at high air density, so low temperatures and low pressure altitudes.

options.A: increases or reduces the power required depending on the airspeed.
options.B: reduces the power required.
options.C: does not affect the power required.
options.D: increases the power required.

key_points: Power required is the power needed at any given speed to overcome the particular amount of drag that exists at that speed
Thrust produced by an engine decreases with altitude because of decreasing air density, which does not allow the engine to burn that much fuel and therefore that much energy to be released
Similarly power available will decrease and the power curve will shift down
learning.explanation: Power required is the power needed at any given speed to overcome the particular amount of drag that exists at that speed. Thrust produced by an engine decreases with altitude because of decreasing air density, which does not allow the engine to burn that much fuel and therefore that much energy to be released. Similarly power available will decrease and the power curve will shift down. However, power required rises with increasing altitude. This is because an aircraft flying at constant lift resulting from constant indicated airspeed and angle of attack will essentially fly at a higher true airspeed at a higher altitude because the loss of air density must be compensated for by an increased speed of flight in order to maintain the required dynamic pressure on the wings.

learning.explanation: Climb gradient and climb angle are two different measures used to describe the rate of ascent of an aircraft. Climb gradient is a measure of the angle of climb expressed as a percentage. It is the ratio of the altitude gained over a certain distance and is usually expressed in terms of feet per nautical mile or meters per kilometer. A climb gradient of 3% means that for every 100 feet (or 30 meters) of distance traveled, the aircraft will climb 3 feet (or 1 meter). Climb angle, on the other hand, is the angle between the aircraft's flight path and the horizontal plane. It is measured in degrees and is a more intuitive measure of the aircraft's rate of ascent. For example, a climb angle of 15 degrees means that the aircraft is climbing at an angle of 15 degrees relative to the horizon.

learning.explanation: Note: There are some quite similar questions to this also on our database, and we are quite sure that there are a few variations on this question on the EASA database also, so do look closely when answering these questions to make sure you are not being caught out by a different question. Propeller aircraft cannot measure thrust output, only power (Power = Thrust x Velocity). This means that it is often useful to change thrust required (drag) graphs into power required graphs, by multiplying by speed (TAS) again. The curve looks the same, but if you get to compare them, the power required curve is steeper and a little to the left. This is where it can get a little complicated, as drag graphs are often created with IAS on the X-axis, for easy usage at all altitudes, but Power = Thrust x True Airspeed. This means that for the same thrust required (drag), an increase in altitude causes a higher TAS and therefore a higher power required. There we have it then; for increased altitude, the power required curve will look almost the same, but for each point on the curve (which is a certain IAS), the TAS will be higher (so the curve moves to the right) and therefore the power required will also be higher (so the graph moves upwards). The graph therefore moves upwards and rightwards, away from the origin, so figure 2 is correct.

A runway is considered to be contaminated when more than 25% of the runway surface area (whether in isolated areas or not) within the required length and width being used is covered by the following: (a) surface water more than 3 mm (0.125 in) deep, or by slush, or loose snow, equivalent to more than 3 mm (0.125 in) of water; (b) snow which has been compressed into a solid mass which resists further compression and will hold together or break into lumps if picked up (compacted snow); or (c) ice, including wet ice. "Damp runway". A runway is considered damp when the surface is not dry, but when the moisture on it does not give it a shiny appearance. "Dry runway". A dry runway is one which is neither wet nor contaminated, and includes those paved runways which have been specially prepared with grooves or porous pavement and maintained to retain "effectively dry" braking action even when moisture is present. "Wet runway." A runway is considered wet when the runway surface is covered with water, or equivalent, less than specified in subparagraph (a)(2) above or when there is sufficient moisture on the runway surface to cause it to appear reflective, but without significant areas of standing water.

content.question: How would you calculate "excess thrust required" in a descent at constant speed?

options.A: Thrust - Lift
options.B: Lift - Drag
options.C: Thrust - Drag
options.D: Drag - Thrust

key_points: Learning Objective 032
learning.explanation: Learning Objective 032.01.05.01.03: Explain the meaning of ‘excess thrust required’ (excess drag) and ‘excess power required’ in a steady descent. Note: There have in the past been some reports of this being seen saying just “excess thrust” in the question, which would be misleading, incorrect and outside of the learning objectives. As indicated in the comments, more recently, the correct wording of “excess thrust required” has been seen instead. Please do report back if it is worded differently in the exam, thanks! In the descent, assuming that the aircraft is maintaining it's speed (and not accelerating), the aircraft's drag must be higher than its forward engine thrust. Therefore, in the forward thrust terms, there is only "negative excess thrust", or “excess thrust required”, or “excess drag”. The excess drag (excess thrust required) is therefore equal to Drag minus Thrust, and this excess drag will have to be equaled by the proportion of weight acting in the direction of travel for a steady descent.

content.question: When to use the formula “9 x square root of the tyre pressure in PSI”?

options.A: For dynamic aqua-planning speed
options.B: For steam hydroplaning speed
options.C: For viscous hydroplaning speed
options.D: For reverted rubber-skidding speed

key_points: Either of the "Aquaplanning" or "Hydroplanning" terms can be used to refer to a condition where the tyre's tread is unable to clear all the surface water from under the wheel
Water is then pushed ahead of the tyre and forms a wedge that lifts the tyre off the runway
This results in a loss of braking and directional control
learning.explanation: Either of the "Aquaplanning" or "Hydroplanning" terms can be used to refer to a condition where the tyre's tread is unable to clear all the surface water from under the wheel. Water is then pushed ahead of the tyre and forms a wedge that lifts the tyre off the runway. This results in a loss of braking and directional control. The tyre can become scalded and blister, as friction causes the water to heat up and eventually boil, as it is pushed along the runway. There are three forms of hydroplanning that should be considered for Contaminated Runway Operations: Dynamic Hydroplanning Viscous Hydroplanning Reverted Rubber Hydroplanning The point at which the aircraft starts to plane is called the Dynamic Hydroplanning speed. This can be approximated from one of the two formulae below: Hydroplanning speed (kt) = 9 x square root(P/ρ), for a rotating tyre (take-off) Hydroplanning speed (kt) = 7.7 x square root(P/ρ), for a non-rotating tyre (landing), where P is the tyre pressure in PSI and ρ is the Specific Gravity (SG) of the contaminant. If the contaminant is water, where SG=1, then the speed might be described as the Dynamic Aquaplanning Speed and the formula given just as: 9 x square root of the tyre pressure in PSI or 7.7 x square root of the tyre pressure in PSI. A thin film or fluid on a smooth runway surface prevents the tyre from making contact with the runway. Viscous Hydroplanning can occur at much lower speeds than dynamic hydroplanning and is most likely on a smooth, dirty surface. Runway touchdown areas are likely to provide these conditions. Reverted Rubber Hydroplanning occurs after a skid, often on the nosewheel which has neither braking nor anti-skid protection. The high temperature created by friction, boil a thin layer of water and vaporised rubber to steam to support the tyre. This is likely if the nosewheel steering is used indiscriminately on a slippery runway. If the take-off is rejected the contaminant which resisted acceleration now becomes as slippery as sin and braking action is drastically reduced.

content.question: For jet-propulsion aeroplanes, the maximum endurance speed corresponds with the...

options.A: Mach long-range.
options.B: Mach maximum-range.
options.C: maximum climb-gradient speed.
options.D: maximum rate-of-climb speed.

key_points: Jet Aircraft Endurance The rate of fuel consumption is a minimum when drag, D, is a minimum
Hence, the maximum endurance flight condition of a jet is at the minimum drag condition (VMD)
Then, the maximum endurance for a jet occurs at the maximum L/D and also corresponds to the Maximum Angle of Climb speed, VX
learning.explanation: Jet Aircraft Endurance The rate of fuel consumption is a minimum when drag, D, is a minimum. Hence, the maximum endurance flight condition of a jet is at the minimum drag condition (VMD). Then, the maximum endurance for a jet occurs at the maximum L/D and also corresponds to the Maximum Angle of Climb speed, VX. VX - Best Angle of Climb Speed The IAS at which the airplane generates the greatest amount of Excess Thrust and is therefore capable of its steepest climb gradient, is called VX. For an airplane powered by jet engines, VX is the same IAS as VMD. VX for a propeller airplane is less than VMD and at low altitudes will be in the region of VMP. The most correct option, in this case, is "Maximum Gradient of Climb Speed". Even though, the correct option should be "Maximum angle of climb speed".

content.question: An air traffic controller clears an aeroplane to climb to FL250 with a minimum required vertical speed of 1500 fpm. The pilot is maintaining a constant CAS of 288 kt, which gives a vertical speed of 1700 fpm whilst climbing through FL100. If the pilot maintains the current settings, what will happen to the vertical speed as the altitude increases?

options.A: The rate of climb will increase as TAS and Mach number increase.
options.B: The rate of climb will remain at approximately 1700 fpm.
options.C: The rate of climb may reduce below the required 1500 fpm.
options.D: The rate of climb will gradually increase up to the cruising altitude.

key_points: As an aircraft climbs, the air becomes less dense, so there will be less air particles to flow through the engine, and be combined with fuel and burnt
This means that thrust available will decrease

In this scenario, the pilot is maintaining a constant CAS (Calibrated Air Speed), which we can assume means they have maximum continuous thrust set, which is the standard climb thrust for a jet aircraft (They are climbing to FL250, so we should assume it is a jet - but a turboprop could also climb that high, and would have exactly the same effect)
learning.explanation: As an aircraft climbs, the air becomes less dense, so there will be less air particles to flow through the engine, and be combined with fuel and burnt. This means that thrust available will decrease. In this scenario, the pilot is maintaining a constant CAS (Calibrated Air Speed), which we can assume means they have maximum continuous thrust set, which is the standard climb thrust for a jet aircraft (They are climbing to FL250, so we should assume it is a jet - but a turboprop could also climb that high, and would have exactly the same effect). In this case, the thrust will gradually reduce, and therefore, the aircraft's rate of climb will gradually reduce, due to a reduction in excess thrust. This will cause the rate of climb to drop below the required 1500 fpm much before reaching FL250.

options.A: increase then decrease.
options.B: decrease.
options.C: increase.
options.D: remains constant.

key_points: In an un-supercharged piston engine, as the altitude (or temperature) increases then the MAP (The manifold pressure) decreases and the power output decreases, too
Accordingly, IAS and TAS also decrease

Superchargers compress the fresh intake air so more fuel/air mixture can be burnt in each power stroke, thereby making the engine more powerful (or allowing it to maintain its power to higher altitudes)
learning.explanation: In an un-supercharged piston engine, as the altitude (or temperature) increases then the MAP (The manifold pressure) decreases and the power output decreases, too. Accordingly, IAS and TAS also decrease. Superchargers compress the fresh intake air so more fuel/air mixture can be burnt in each power stroke, thereby making the engine more powerful (or allowing it to maintain its power to higher altitudes). The supercharged engines maintain their power output to a higher altitude, but above the "Full Throttle Height", where the supercharger is no longer able to maintain the MAP, then the power output decreases above that.

content.question: How does a headwind affect an aircraft's maximum endurance at VMD (jet aircraft) / VMP (propeller aircraft)?

options.A: Increases.
options.B: Decreases.
options.C: Increases in a jet aircraft, decreases in a propeller aircraft.
options.D: Maximum endurance is not affected by wind.

key_points: Note: This is very similar to question 327609, but it is possible that both may be present in the question banks in different authorities
Endurance is the time that the aircraft can remain airborne

Maximum Endurance Speed is the airspeed at which the aircraft burns the least possible amount of fuel, the minimum drag is produced and the minimum thrust is required, thus the maximum airborne time (maximum endurance) is gained
learning.explanation: Note: This is very similar to question 327609, but it is possible that both may be present in the question banks in different authorities. Endurance is the time that the aircraft can remain airborne. Maximum Endurance Speed is the airspeed at which the aircraft burns the least possible amount of fuel, the minimum drag is produced and the minimum thrust is required, thus the maximum airborne time (maximum endurance) is gained. For turbojet aeroplanes, this Maximum Endurance Speed is the VMD. The Maximum Endurance Speed for propeller aircraft is the VMP. Unlike range, endurance is not affected by the wind conditions, since it is only affected by the airspeed selection and availability of the fuel onboard. Also, the Maximum Endurance Speed, as an airspeed, is unaffected by the wind.

content.question: In the take-off climb segment, a MEP aircraft has a gross gradient of 13% with all engines operating and a gross gradient of 5.2% with one engine inoperative. Which net gradients must be used for the calculation of obstacle clearance if the cloud base is at 600 ft?

options.A: 13% below the cloud base and 5.2% above.
options.B: 10% below the cloud base and 4% above.
options.C: 13% below the cloud base and 4% above.
options.D: 10% below the cloud base and 5.2% above.

key_points: EASA AIR OPS CAT
POL
A
learning.explanation: EASA AIR OPS CAT. POL. A.310 Take-off obstacle clearance – multi-engined aeroplanes 3) failure of the critical engine occurs at the point on the all engine take-off flight path where visual reference for the purpose of avoiding obstacles is expected to be lost; (4) the gradient of the take-off flight path from 50 ft to the assumed engine failure height is equal to the average all-engines gradient during climb and transition to the en-route configuration, multiplied by a factor of 0,77; and (5) the gradient of the take-off flight path from the height reached in accordance with (a)(4) to the end of the take-off flight path is equal to the OEI en-route climb gradient shown in the AFM. The all-engine gradient is used up to the cloudbase and the OEI gradient is used thereafter. For the all-engine gradient, there is a large safety margin between gross and net gradient: Net = Gross x 0.77 => 13% x 0.77 = 10.01% No safety margin is applied to the OEI gradient: Net = Gross => 5.2%

learning.explanation: IMPORTANT NOTE: This is a HPL question and is out of the scope of Performance (032). However, a student has reported that he came across this question in his Performance exam. NARROW RUNWAY A narrower-than-usual runway can create an illusion that the aircraft is higher than it actually is. If you believe this illusion, you may pitch the aircraft’s nose down to lose altitude. If this happens too close to the ground, you may land short of the runway and cause an accident. content.question: For a propeller aircraft, the speed for maximum endurance which gives the greatest endurance time is:

options.A: Found at a low altitude.
options.B: Altitude is irrelevant.
options.C: Dependant on the OAT.
options.D: Found at a high altitude.

key_points: Fuel flow is largely proportional to engine power, which in turn is largely proportional to power required (there are some efficiencies involved but that depends on the exact combination of engine and prop - we're interested in the general rule here)
Theoretical power required is TAS x drag (not IAS!)
Drag is determined by IAS however
learning.explanation: Fuel flow is largely proportional to engine power, which in turn is largely proportional to power required (there are some efficiencies involved but that depends on the exact combination of engine and prop - we're interested in the general rule here). Theoretical power required is TAS x drag (not IAS!). Drag is determined by IAS however. Therefore, maximum endurance is reached by finding an optimum of the product IAS x drag, and then making sure TAS is as small as possible for this IAS. At higher altitude, a given IAS results in a higher TAS and consequently more power required. To minimise power required and fuel burn, increasing our endurance, the aircraft should fly at lower altitudes. Maximum edurance for a propeller aircraft is at sea level.

content.question: How does the maximum specific range over the Ground (SRG) for a propeller driven aeroplane vary with altitude?

options.A: It increases until the increase in TAS is offset by the increase in power required.
options.B: It increases until the increase in the Ground speed is offset by the increase in power required.
options.C: It decreases until the decrease in TAS is offset by the increase in power required.
options.D: It decreases until the increase in Ground speed is offset by the increase in power required.

key_points: Maximum Specific Range over the Ground (SRG) is the greatest ground range covered for a specific fuel flow
The specific fuel consumption (SFC) for a turbine engine improves its efficiency as the temperature decreases
That means that, SFC will reduce as the aircraft climbs towards the tropopause and then once in stratosphere it stays broadly the same as the aircraft continues to climb
learning.explanation: Maximum Specific Range over the Ground (SRG) is the greatest ground range covered for a specific fuel flow. The specific fuel consumption (SFC) for a turbine engine improves its efficiency as the temperature decreases. That means that, SFC will reduce as the aircraft climbs towards the tropopause and then once in stratosphere it stays broadly the same as the aircraft continues to climb. SFC also increases almost linearly as speed increases. Thus, the SFC occurs at low IAS, at low temperatures and at high altitudes. The greatest SRG will occur when we get the highest GS for the lowest power required. Thus, for a propeller aeroplane, the increase in power required, caused by an increasing TAS in the climb, offsets the gains in SFC and SRG as you climb.

content.question: With regard to the effect of altitude on the speed for maximum endurance for a propeller-driven aeroplane, as altitude increases, the speed for maximum endurance will…

options.A: decrease, because aeroplane drag decreases with altitude.
options.B: increase, because aeroplane drag increases with altitude.
options.C: increase, because the power required increases with altitude.
options.D: decrease, because the power required decreases with altitude.

key_points: Propeller aeroplanes are measured by power production, rather than the thrust measurement of jet engines
Power is the rate of doing work, and is the amount of thrust x True Air Speed
As thrust required = drag, we can say Power Required = Drag x TAS
learning.explanation: Propeller aeroplanes are measured by power production, rather than the thrust measurement of jet engines. Power is the rate of doing work, and is the amount of thrust x True Air Speed. As thrust required = drag, we can say Power Required = Drag x TAS. Also, the maximum endurance speed for a propeller aircraft is the speed at which it is producing the least engine power, minimum power speed (VMP). In propeller aeroplanes we tend to fly at a constant IAS/CAS and accept the TAS that results, as this allows us to have a constant stall speed (and other speeds) at any altitude. When we maintain our IAS and fly higher, we get a higher TAS to account for the lower air density, and still give us the same lift force. This means that at higher altitude, the TAS increases, so therefore the power required increases as well. As Power Required is based on TAS, it means we also measure the speed for minimum power (VMP) in terms of TAS as well, which increases with altitude, so therefore VMP (which is Maximum Endurance speed) increases.

content.question: A large jet transport aeroplane is cruising at the Long Range Cruise speed (LRC). A deviation of +/- 1000 ft from the LRC optimum altitude leads to 2.5% change in specific range. The specific range will change by (1) _____ if flying 1000 ft above the optimum altitude, and by (2) _____ if flying 2000 ft below the optimum altitude.

key_points: The optimum altitude of an aeroplane is the altitude where it produce the highest specific range
This means that it requires a high speed and low fuel consumption

For a jet aircraft, this occurs at high altitudes, where the jet engines are running at approximately 90% RPM, and the thrust produced allows the aircraft to fly at its best range speed (IAS), for best speed to drag ratio
learning.explanation: The optimum altitude of an aeroplane is the altitude where it produce the highest specific range. This means that it requires a high speed and low fuel consumption. For a jet aircraft, this occurs at high altitudes, where the jet engines are running at approximately 90% RPM, and the thrust produced allows the aircraft to fly at its best range speed (IAS), for best speed to drag ratio. It is usually quite close to an aircraft's maximum altitude (for a jet), and above or below it will be a less efficient altitude. If the aircraft is below its optimum altitude, then the engines will be running at a lower RPM to produce the same speed due to the higher air density, which is less efficient, or the aircraft will fly faster for the same engine RPM, which causes higher drag, and is less efficient. If the aircraft is above its optimum altitude, then the engines will be running at a higher RPM (closer to 100%), which reduces efficiency again, increasing fuel burn and engine wear. This question tells us by how much our fuel burn is affected when off altitude, and you simply multiply the percentage by how many 1000's of feet different from the optimum altitude the aircraft is, and the change is always a reduction in specific range. Sometimes the penalty for being off altitude is shown in a table, as seen in the annex above.

options.C: Prior to touchdown because automatic braking systems must be used to determine the landing distance.
options.D: On first wheel touchdown, maximum manual braking is applied to achieve the shortest possible landing distance.

key_points: According to the AMC CS 25

125(c) - Landing: During measured landings, if the brakes can be consistently applied in a manner permitting the nose gear to touch down safely, the brakes may be applied with only the main wheels firmly on the ground
Otherwise, the brakes should not be applied until all wheels are firmly on the ground
learning.explanation: According to the AMC CS 25.125(c) - Landing: During measured landings, if the brakes can be consistently applied in a manner permitting the nose gear to touch down safely, the brakes may be applied with only the main wheels firmly on the ground. Otherwise, the brakes should not be applied until all wheels are firmly on the ground. This is not intended to prevent operation in the normal way of automatic braking systems which, for instance, permit brakes to be selected on before touchdown. content.question: For a given aeroplane mass, a more aft CG position will...

options.A: decrease the take-off distance and improve the take-off climb performance.
options.B: increase the take-off distance and reduce the take-off climb performance.
options.C: increase the take-off distance and improve the take-off climb performance.
options.D: decrease the take-off distance and reduce the take-off climb performance.

key_points: CG position VS Aircraft’s performance A tail down force (created by the elevator) exists to balance the moment created between the CG and CP of the wing
Essentially, the tail works as an upside down wing which generates lift downwards
The amount of lift it needs to generate will depend on CG position and aircraft weight
learning.explanation: CG position VS Aircraft’s performance A tail down force (created by the elevator) exists to balance the moment created between the CG and CP of the wing. Essentially, the tail works as an upside down wing which generates lift downwards. The amount of lift it needs to generate will depend on CG position and aircraft weight. Consequently, when the CG moves forward and aft, tail down force and lift required for a stable flight will change. FORWARD CG increases the pitch down moment tendency of the aircraft. Therefore, greater horizontal stabilizer and elevator deflections are needed to give the aircraft a pitch-up attitude to compensate for the pitch-down moment. Extra lift is generated by increasing the angle of attack, which in turn increases induced drag. Thus performance decreases. For take-off, if the CG position is too far forward, the aircraft is said to have a “heavy nose”. Conversely, as the CG MOVES REARWARD, the aircraft will experience a reduced pitch down moment tendency, resulting in less tail-down force being required. As a consequence, drag decreases (and so does stalling speed) which improves performance. Since Climb gradient is a product of excess of thrust over drag, climb performance will be improved. For take-off, if the CG position is too far aft, the aircraft is said to have a “light nose” making the rotation easier. Additionally, an aircraft which requires less lift will have a slower rotation speed, which results in a reduced take-off distance. To simplify this concept and make it easier to answer these type of question you can think of a forward CG as having the same effects as a heavy aircraft; and an aft CG as having the same result as a light aircraft.

content.question: In aircraft performance calculations, which of the following correctly describes "gross", "calculated" and "net" climb gradients with respect to safety margins?

options.A: The "gross" climb gradient already includes a safety margin, while the "calculated climb gradient" and "actual climb gradient" do not include a safety margin.
options.B: The "gross" climb gradient does not include a safety margin, while the "calculated climb gradient" and "actual climb gradient" already include a safety margin.
options.C: All three terms, "gross climb gradient", "calculated climb gradient," and "actual climb gradient," include safety margins.
options.D: The "gross" climb gradient, "calculated climb gradient," and "actual climb gradient" are all different terms for the same value, and none of them include a safety margin.

key_points: When aircraft are being certified, the manufacturer must test the aircraft in many different ways to define certain levels of performance for many phases of flight, such as take-off distance, maximum rate of climb, landing distance and many more
There are different types of performance categorisation: Measured Performance is the performance achieved by the manufacturer under test conditions for certification

It utilises new aeroplanes and the test pilots, and is therefore not representative of the actual performance that any single aircraft might be able to achieve in normal circumstances, flown by a normal pilot
learning.explanation: When aircraft are being certified, the manufacturer must test the aircraft in many different ways to define certain levels of performance for many phases of flight, such as take-off distance, maximum rate of climb, landing distance and many more. There are different types of performance categorisation: Measured Performance is the performance achieved by the manufacturer under test conditions for certification. It utilises new aeroplanes and the test pilots, and is therefore not representative of the actual performance that any single aircraft might be able to achieve in normal circumstances, flown by a normal pilot. Gross Performance is the expected fleet average of aeroplanes, given that they are sufficiently maintained and flown as per the techniques detailed in the flight manuals, by a normal pilot. This means that any aircraft in the fleet has a 50% chance of exceeding this performance, but also a 50% chance of not meeting this performance. Net Performance is the gross performance, reduced by the safety margin, to account for various possibilities that could commonly cause reduced performance, such as variations in pilot technique, below-average aircraft performance, etc. The safety margin is set so that the chance of an aircraft not meeting the net performance level is extremely low. The safety margin is not fixed, It depends on the likelihood of the situation occurring, and is set to make sure that the total probability of an incident or accident occurring is at least lower than 1 in 1 million, when a passenger buys their ticket (known as their “remote probability”). This might mean that the safety margin (between gross and net performance) is large for likely events such as a take-off with all engines operating, but the safety margin is very low or even zero for unlikely events such as an engine failure at V1. So now we know that the gross climb gradient does NOT include a safety margin, which removes two possible answers. It then depends on how you interpret the two other answers, and whether the "actual" or "calculated" climb gradients can be said to contain a safety margin or not. "Actual climb gradient" can be argued either way in our opinion, it could contain a safety margin by the fact that the aircraft achieving a certain gradient needs no further safety reduction (is already corrected from the performance figures by real life performance), or you could say that no further reduction to that gradient is required, so no safety margin is included. "Calculated climb gradient", on the other hand, could mean either gross or net climb gradient, as they are both calculated. One with a safety margin, the other is without. Option D says that the 3 terms are the same, which is certainly NOT true as "gross" and "actual" are not usually the same, so that leaves us with only one option remaining, and it assumes that "calculated" means "net", and that "actual climb gradient" includes a safety margin. NOTE: Having only received one count of feedback for this question, we cannot confirm that this will be exactly replicated in your real exam, so please do let us know in the comments if you see this question, and whatever you might be able to remember from it, thank you!

content.question: What happens to jet endurance with altitude?

options.A: Endurance is maximum at low levels with MCT set.
options.B: Endurance is maximum at a high level, low OAT, and design RPM.
options.C: Endurance can be maximized by flying with minimal fuel load at high the highest possible altitude.
options.D: Endurance increases above the optimum altitude due to reduced density.

key_points: The endurance of an aeroplane is the time it can remain airborne on a given quantity of fuel or, put another way, endurance can be expressed as fuel used over a given airborne time
For a jet aeroplane, Fuel Flow = Fuel Flow per unit Thrust (SFC) x Total Thrust The aim is to reduce the amount of fuel used to produce each thrust unit (SFC needs to be small)
For a jet engine this occurs when ambient temperature is very low and engine rpm is very high
learning.explanation: The endurance of an aeroplane is the time it can remain airborne on a given quantity of fuel or, put another way, endurance can be expressed as fuel used over a given airborne time. For a jet aeroplane, Fuel Flow = Fuel Flow per unit Thrust (SFC) x Total Thrust The aim is to reduce the amount of fuel used to produce each thrust unit (SFC needs to be small). For a jet engine this occurs when ambient temperature is very low and engine rpm is very high. This can only occur at high altitude. So, flying at high altitude, minimizes the fuel used per unit of thrust. In level flight the forward acting force of thrust is controlled and balanced by the rearward acting force of drag. If drag is small, the aeroplane need fly with only a small amount of thrust. Therefore, on the formula above, “Total Thrust” can be replaced by “Total Drag”. To minimize drag, the jet aeroplane simply flies at the velocity for minimum drag. In summary then, for a jet aeroplane to maximize its endurance by minimizing its fuel flow, the pilot would fly the aeroplane at VMD and fly as high as possible.

content.question:
Determine the one-engine-out climb gradient of a four-engined aeroplane, given:
Aeroplane mass: 315 000 kg
Thrust per engine: 245 000 N
Drag: 435 000 N
(Assume the acceleration due to gravity is 10 m/s2)

key_points: Thrust (T) = Number of Engines (4 - 1 inop) x Thrust per Engine T = 3 x 245 000 N = 735 000 N Weight (W) = Aeroplane Mass x 10 m/s2 W = 315 000 kg x 10 m/s2 = 3 150 000 N Climb gradient = [(Thrust - Drag) / Weight ] x 100% Climb gradient = [(735 000 - 435 000) / 3 150 000 ] x 100% = 9
learning.explanation: Thrust (T) = Number of Engines (4 - 1 inop) x Thrust per Engine T = 3 x 245 000 N = 735 000 N Weight (W) = Aeroplane Mass x 10 m/s2 W = 315 000 kg x 10 m/s2 = 3 150 000 N Climb gradient = [(Thrust - Drag) / Weight ] x 100% Climb gradient = [(735 000 - 435 000) / 3 150 000 ] x 100% = 9.5%

content.question: From FL50 to 500 ft above the destination aerodrome, a multi-engined piston (MEP) aeroplane performs a steady descent, maintaining a constant speed of 120 kt IAS. During this descent, the ‘’Power Required vs. TAS’’ curve will move (1) _____ and the ‘’Power Available vs. TAS’’ curve will move (2) _____.

options.A: (1) up and right; (2) down and right
options.B: (1) down and right; (2) up and right
options.C: (1) up and left; (2) down and left
options.D: (1) down and left; (2) up and left

key_points: Power required is the power needed at any given speed to overcome the particular amount of drag that exists at that speed

Power = Thrust x Speed (TAS) Power required = Thrust Required x Speed (TAS) Thrust produced by an engine decreases with altitude because of decreasing air density, which does not allow the engine to burn as much fuel, and create as big explosions
Similarly, power available will decrease with increasing altitude
learning.explanation: Power required is the power needed at any given speed to overcome the particular amount of drag that exists at that speed. Power = Thrust x Speed (TAS) Power required = Thrust Required x Speed (TAS) Thrust produced by an engine decreases with altitude because of decreasing air density, which does not allow the engine to burn as much fuel, and create as big explosions. Similarly, power available will decrease with increasing altitude. However, power required rises with increasing altitude. This is because the aircraft flying at constant lift resulting from constant Indicated Airspeed and angle of attack will essentially fly at a higher True Airspeed at a higher altitude because the loss of air density must be compensated for by an increased speed of flight to maintain the required dynamic pressure on the wings. It is important to note for this next section that the shape of the thrust required / available graphs are based on IAS initially, but are converted to TAS to be more useful with Power Required / Power Available, which are created from the thrust graphs using TAS via the formulas above. In this question, then, we are descending, so we are expecting our Power Required to decrease, and our TAS for each point on the graph to decrease also, so the Power Required vs. TAS graph will move down and to the left. Also, the Power Available will increase as we descend into denser air, and the TAS will also decrease for every point on the graph, the same as before, to make the Power Available vs TAS graph move up and to the left. The annex above shows what happens to the curves when the aircraft descends (as in this question).

content.question: An uphill slope:

options.A: increases the take-off distance available.
options.B: increases the accelerated-stop-distance available.
options.C: increases the accelerated-stop-distance required.
options.D: decreases the take-off distance required.

key_points: If the runway is sloping, a component of the weight acts along the runway and increases or decreases the acceleration force
A downhill slope increases the accelerating force, and therefore reduces the takeoff distance required, whereas an uphill slope reduces the accelerating force and increases the takeoff distance
In most cases the published aeroplane performance data gives take-off and landing distance assuming a level runway
learning.explanation: If the runway is sloping, a component of the weight acts along the runway and increases or decreases the acceleration force. A downhill slope increases the accelerating force, and therefore reduces the takeoff distance required, whereas an uphill slope reduces the accelerating force and increases the takeoff distance. In most cases the published aeroplane performance data gives take-off and landing distance assuming a level runway. In the case of a sloping runway the effect of gravity will be to shorten the take-off run required (TORR) and the take-off distance required (TODR) when the slope is downhill. An uphill slope will provide the opposite effect, increasing TORR and TODR. In the case of landing a downhill sloping runway will extend the landing distance required (LDR), whereas an uphill slope will decrease it. Consequently, it may be necessary to reduce the aircraft weight for an uphill take-off or a downhill landing. It should also be borne in mind that, as with the landing case, an abandoned take-off will require a greater stopping distance on a down- sloping runway.

content.question: The rate of climb...

options.A: is approximately climb gradient times true airspeed divided by 100
options.B: is the horizontal component of the true airspeed
options.C: is angle of climb times true airspeed
options.D: is the downhill component of the true airspeed

key_points: The Rate of Climb (RoC) is the aircraft's vertical speed, the height gained per unit of time, usually expressed in feet per minute
Considering an aircraft in a steady climb, the RoC is affected by the TAS and the climb angle: RoC = TAS x Sin Climb angle
During climb with a steady speed, the thrust and the two retarding effects of aerodynamic drag and the weight element must be equal: T = D + W x Sin Climb angle
learning.explanation: The Rate of Climb (RoC) is the aircraft's vertical speed, the height gained per unit of time, usually expressed in feet per minute. Considering an aircraft in a steady climb, the RoC is affected by the TAS and the climb angle: RoC = TAS x Sin Climb angle. During climb with a steady speed, the thrust and the two retarding effects of aerodynamic drag and the weight element must be equal: T = D + W x Sin Climb angle. Solving for Sin Climb angle, we get: Sin Climb angle = (T - D) / W. If we recognise that for small angles the Sine in the climb equals to the Tangent and that Tangent in turn is the amount of height gained per unit of distance, we get an approximate formula for the Climb Gradient: %Climb Gradient = (T - D) x 100 / W. Therefore, RoC = (Climb gradient x TAS), approximately.

content.question: A difference between a reduced (flex) and a derated thrust take-off is that...

options.A: on a flex take-off, the TOGA thrust remains available.
options.B: derated thrust take-offs use an assumed temperature.
options.C: the flex thrust is regarded as an operating limit.
options.D: flex take-offs can be conducted on contaminated runways.

key_points: When an aircraft has excess performance during takeoff, using maximum thrust is unnecessary and choosing a lower thrust setting offers benefits in engine life and costs
Two procedures exist: flex takeoff and derated thrust takeoff
The flex take-off is achieved by calculating an assumed or flex temperature that is higher than the ambient which will, when entered into the FMS, give a thrust setting lower than full thrust
learning.explanation: When an aircraft has excess performance during takeoff, using maximum thrust is unnecessary and choosing a lower thrust setting offers benefits in engine life and costs. Two procedures exist: flex takeoff and derated thrust takeoff. The flex take-off is achieved by calculating an assumed or flex temperature that is higher than the ambient which will, when entered into the FMS, give a thrust setting lower than full thrust. The flex temperature will always be higher than the ambient temperature. On a flex take-off the reduced thrust setting for take-off will not need to be increased if there is an engine failure but, in emergency, it can be. Full thrust may be applied at any time. According to AMC 25-13: "When operating with reduced (flex) take-off thrust, the thrust setting parameter, which establishes thrust for take-off, is not considered a take-off operating limit". Because full thrust can be applied at any time on a flex take-off, the speeds VMCG and VMCA must be corrected for full thrust, not the reduced thrust setting. A flex take-off is not considered to be a normal take-off, is always at the discretion of the pilot and is not authorised on wet runways, unless suitable performance accountability is made for the increased stopping distance on a wet runway. As most operators account for this, we can assume that flex thrust take-offs are allowed on a wet runway, but not on a contaminated runway. Throughout the flex take-off, a further thrust selection of the Take-off/Go Around (TOGA) is availablle. AMC 25-13 defines derated thrust as a take-off thrust less than the maximum take-off thrust, for which exists in the AFM a set of separate and independent, or clearly distinguishable, take-off limitations and performance data that complies with all the take-off requirements of CS-25. When operating with a derated take-off thrust, the value of the thrust setting parameter, which establishes thrust for take-off, is presented in the AFM and is considered a normal take-off operating limit. A derated thrust take-off is considered to be a normal take-off and therefore can be carried out both on dry runwaysand on wet and contaminated runways, subject to the AFM data and other operating restrictions. Because the take-off speeds are calculated at the lower thrust, the derated thrust setting is considered to be a limit and therefore full thrust or TOGA thrust cannot be selected, even in an emergency, until the hazard area for VMCG is well passed. Airbus, for instance, does not allow TOGA to be selected on a derated take-off, until the aircraft has achieved the minimum flap retraction speed.

learning.explanation: Maximum endurance speed is the speed which permits the maximum airborne time, thus the minimum fuel consumption is required. For a propeller-driven aeroplane, either turboprop or piston engine, the Specific Fuel Consumption (SFC) is fuel flow/power. Solving for fuel flow, we get that for a given SFC, the fuel flow is proportional to the power required, not the thrust. key_points: Power required is the power needed at any given speed to overcome the particular amount of drag that exists at that speed
Power required = Thrust Required x speed Thrust produced by an engine decreases with altitude because of decreasing air density, which does not allow the engine to burn that much fuel
Similarly, power available will decrease
learning.explanation: Power required is the power needed at any given speed to overcome the particular amount of drag that exists at that speed. Power required = Thrust Required x speed Thrust produced by an engine decreases with altitude because of decreasing air density, which does not allow the engine to burn that much fuel. Similarly, power available will decrease. However, power required rises with increasing altitude. This is because the aircraft flying at constant lift resulting from constant indicated airspeed and angle of attack will essentially fly at a higher True Airspeed at a higher altitude because the loss of air density must be compensated for by an increased speed of flight to maintain the required dynamic pressure on the wings.

content.question: Whilst following a constant-descent approach profile, an aircraft turns onto final approach with the Auto-Throttle engaged in speed hold mode and the A/P in vertical speed mode, and the crosswind changes into a headwind. How does this wind condition affect the aircraft, and what measures must the pilot take on the turn onto final?

options.A: The aircraft's GS will decrease, and the pilot must decrease the vertical speed to stay on the flight path.
options.B: The aircraft's GS will increase, and the pilot must increase the vertical speed to stay on the flight path.
options.C: The pilot must extend the flaps, which will require a change to the Auto-Throttle settings.
options.D: The aircraft's behaviour will not be affected if the flaps are extended during the turn to final.

key_points: In this scenario, the aircraft's indicated airspeed is being held constant by the A/T (Auto-Throttle) and the Rate of Descent is being held constant by the A/P (Autopilot), and they are on profile to complete a constant descent approach
When turning from base onto final approach, the shifting wind will cause a change in the groundspeed first
As the same IAS is being flown, going from a crosswind to a headwind, the groundspeed is lower on final than it was on base
learning.explanation: In this scenario, the aircraft's indicated airspeed is being held constant by the A/T (Auto-Throttle) and the Rate of Descent is being held constant by the A/P (Autopilot), and they are on profile to complete a constant descent approach. When turning from base onto final approach, the shifting wind will cause a change in the groundspeed first. As the same IAS is being flown, going from a crosswind to a headwind, the groundspeed is lower on final than it was on base. As approaches require a constant angle of descent, therefore, the aircraft will have to change it's rate of descent to maintain the same approach angle (usually 3º). If the aircraft did not change rate of descent, it will descend at the same amount of feet per minute, but take longer than expected to reach the Runway, so would get low on profile. The rate of descent on an approach is directly proportional to the groundspeed (for a 3º glidepath, the rate of descent [ft/min] is the GS [kt] x 5), and therefore a reduction in groundspeed requires a reduction in the rate of descent (the pilot must decrease the vertical speed). Note that the flaps are not required to modify the rate of descent here. The flaps are used to allow us to fly slower during the descent, approach and landing, and increase drag which can be useful to help us descend, but in this scenario, there is no change to IAS or need for greater drag, so the flap setting does not need to change on this final turn, and if it did, the flaps would cause a change to the aircraft's behaviour (a balloon effect), but would not require a change to the A/T settings.

content.question: A multi-engined piston aeroplane is in straight and level flight. As fuel is burnt, the mass of the aeroplane reduces. Consequently, the Specific Range (SR) will (1) _____, and the optimum speed for maximum SR will (2) _____.

options.B: (1) decrease; (2) decrease.
options.C: (1) decrease; (2) increase.

key_points: Learning Objective 032
learning.explanation: Learning Objective 032.01.03.02.05: Explain the effect of aeroplane weight and CG position on fuel consumption, range and the optimum speed for maximum SR. SPECIFIC RANGE Specific Range (SR) is one of the measures of efficiency for an aircraft, as it is the distance the aircraft can fly per unit of fuel used (higher is better). The easiest formula for it is: Specific Range = TAS/Fuel Flow The optimum speed for maximum SR is when the TAS is the highest for the lowest fuel flow. As a general rule, the fuel flow of an engine is approximately proportional to the power. Therefore, the SR is highest when TAS is highest for the least power required. This point occurs at VMD for a propeller aircraft, as seen on the graph in the first annex above. As the aircraft becomes lighter, less lift is required to overcome the weight, so the lift induced drag section of the drag curve reduces. This brings the total drag curve down and to the left of the graph, so there is less drag overall (higher SR) and the point of highest SR (VMD) occurs at a slightly lower speed. The graph is usually IAS vs power required, but in this comparison it is fine to use TAS. Also, the graph looks very similar for a jet aircraft, but uses 1.32 x VMD for the point of highest SR. The second annex above shows how weight affects an aircraft's drag (and power required) curve.

content.question: You are in a multi-engine aircraft equipped with counter-rotating propellers, which rotate away from the cockpit when viewed from behind. In the case of an engine failure, which engine is critical?

options.A: There is no critical engine as counter-rotating blades always generate a p-factor closest to the cockpit.
options.B: The left engine is critical.
options.C: The right engine is critical.
options.D: Both engines are critical.

key_points: Note: This question is very poorly written
When both engines rotate "outwards", both engines have a worse effect in the event of an engine failure than if they rotated "inwards"
This does not, however, mean they are both critical
learning.explanation: Note: This question is very poorly written. When both engines rotate "outwards", both engines have a worse effect in the event of an engine failure than if they rotated "inwards". This does not, however, mean they are both critical. A critical engine is one which has a worse effect than the other in the event of an engine failure, so both engines cannot be critical. Nonetheless, we have chosen the option that "both engines are critical" as they both have the worst case thrust asymmetry if an engine fails, and the other options were not correct at all. The critical engine of a multi-engine, fixed-wing propeller-driven aircraft is the one whose failure would result in the most adverse effects on the aircraft's handling and performance. When one of the engines on a typical multi-engine aircraft becomes inoperative, a thrust asymmetry exists. The thrust asymmetry can be different, depending on how the engine is mounted. Particularly on a propeller aircraft, the propellers are subject to the asymmetric blade effect, called P-factor. This occurs because the propeller does not spin perpendicular to the airflow, as the aircraft is flying with an angle of attack. This means that the down-going blades on the propeller have a higher angle of attack and longer track, so they produce more thrust. Therefore, the thrust vector of the engine is located not centrally, but more towards the down-going blade side. The annex above shows an aircraft with both engine rotating to the right. This means that one engine has its thrust vector further from the aircraft's longitudinal axis, and therefore if the other engine fails, it has a worse effect on yaw. This engine (with the worst effect on yaw) is called the critical engine. In the case of this question though, both engines have their thrust vector further from the longitudinal axis, so the aircraft has a worse response from either engine failing. In this question, none of the engines have a P-factor closest to the cockpit. That option is not quite correct in its current form.

Operating at "off-optimum" altitude, incurs both fuel and mileage penalty. key_points: Best Angle of climb speed (VX) is found at the maximum excess of Thrust – in other words, where the gap between the “Thrust” available and Thrust Required “Drag” curves is the greatest
Weight has a very pronounced effect on aircraft performance
If weight is added to an aircraft, it must fly at a higher AOA to maintain a given altitude and speed
learning.explanation: Best Angle of climb speed (VX) is found at the maximum excess of Thrust – in other words, where the gap between the “Thrust” available and Thrust Required “Drag” curves is the greatest. Weight has a very pronounced effect on aircraft performance. If weight is added to an aircraft, it must fly at a higher AOA to maintain a given altitude and speed. This increases the induced drag of the wings, as well as the parasite drag of the aircraft. Increased drag means that additional thrust is needed to overcome it, which in turn means that less reserve thrust is available for climbing. This moves the Total Drag curve up, but also to the right. Thrust Required is increased and VX is a faster IAS. Best Rate of climb speed (VY) is found at the maximum excess of Power – in other words, where the gap between the “Power” available and Power Required curves is the greatest. As weight increases, the power required curve moves up and to the right. As a result, less excess Power is available and, therefore, the rate of climb decreases. However, as you can see, the speed for maximum Excess Power available is higher. Summary: higher Weight => decreased rate of climb => increased VY speed.

learning.explanation: This is not supposed to be a Performance question, and is much closer to an instrumentation question, but has been reported as seen in Performance exams recently (as well as very similar questions in PoF exams). If the pitot tubes get blocked in the climb, but the static ports remain free, then the indicated airspeed will initially stop changing with airspeed, and will now gradually increase with altitude as the static pressure reduces (the airspeed indicator now acts like an altimeter). In the climb, this may not be noticeable for a while, and might not be noticed at all if the autopilot was in certain modes, such as those which maintain a constant rate of climb (assuming constant thrust). Whatever happens, as the aircraft continues to climb, the actual airspeed is unknown whilst the indicated airspeed (IAS) is showing a continuous increase. This is particularly dangerous in modes such as level change or flight level change, which maintain a constant airspeed/Mach No. in the climb, as the aircraft would pitch up more and more to try to reduce the "increasing airspeed", stalling the aircraft quite quickly. If the aircraft does not stall beforehand, then when maximum airspeed is reached, the pilots or autopilot/autothrottle will either reduce thrust or pitch up to avoid further airspeed increase, which will very quickly lead to a stall. As for the other options, the air data computer, autopilot and autothrottle systems have the same pitot inputs as the pilots do, so will not be able to protect the aircraft from this condition, that is one of the reasons that probe icing and blockages are so dangerous.

key_points: When aircraft are being certified, the manufacturer must test the aircraft in many different ways to define certain levels of performance for many phases of flight, such as take-off distance, maximum rate of climb, landing distance and many more
There are different types of performance categorisation
Measured Performance is the performance achieved by the manufacturer under test conditions for certification
learning.explanation: When aircraft are being certified, the manufacturer must test the aircraft in many different ways to define certain levels of performance for many phases of flight, such as take-off distance, maximum rate of climb, landing distance and many more. There are different types of performance categorisation. Measured Performance is the performance achieved by the manufacturer under test conditions for certification. It utilises new aeroplanes and the test pilots, and is therefore not representative of the actual performance that any single aircraft might be able to achieve in normal circumstances, flown by a normal pilot. Gross Performance is the expected fleet average of aeroplanes, given that they are sufficiently maintained and flown as per the techniques detailed in the flight manuals, by a normal pilot. This means that any aircraft in the fleet has a 50% chance of exceeding this performance, but also a 50% chance of not meeting this performance. Net Performance is the gross performance, reduced by the safety margin, to account for various possibilities that could commonly cause reduced performance, such as variations in pilot technique, below-average aircraft performance, etc. The safety margin is set so that the chance of an aircraft not meeting the net performance level is extremely low. The safety margin is not fixed, It depends on the likelihood of the situation occurring, and is set to make sure that the total probability of an incident or accident occurring is at least lower than 1 in 1 million, when a passenger buys their ticket (known as their “remote probability”). This might mean that the safety margin (between gross and net performance) is large for likely events such as a take-off with all engines operating, but the safety margin is very low or even zero for unlikely events such as an engine failure at V1.

We have not been told whether the aircraft is multi-engine or single-engine, but neither is having a good day. In a multi, the procedure is called a drift-down, and is effectively the aircraft losing height as slowly as possible (with the remaining engine(s) running at max continuous thrust), until the aircraft gets low enough to be able to maintain height on the working engine(s). In a single, it is just gliding to the safest place possible. Nonetheless, in both scenarios we want to extend our glide or drift-down range as far as possible. learning.explanation: Propeller aircraft cannot measure thrust output, only power (Power = Thrust x Velocity). This means that it is often useful to change thrust required (drag) graphs into power required graphs, by multiplying by speed (TAS) again. The curve looks the same, but if you get to compare them, the power required curve is steeper and a little to the left. This is where it can get a little complicated, as drag graphs are often created with IAS on the X-axis, for easy usage at all altitudes, but Power = Thrust x True Airspeed. This means that for the same thrust required (drag), an increase in altitude causes a higher TAS and therefore a higher power required. There we have it then; for increased altitude, the power required curve will look almost the same, but for each point on the curve (which is a certain IAS), the TAS will be higher (so the curve moves to the right) and therefore the power required will also be higher (so the graph moves upwards). The graph therefore moves upwards and rightwards, away from the origin, so figure (d) is correct.

learning.explanation: EFFECT OF FLAPS ON LANDING/TAKE-OFF RUN AND CLIMB GRADIENT The use of high lift devices (Flaps) will have an impact on the take-off and Landing roll and climb gradient. For a given runway length and airplane weight, selecting a greater flap setting will increase the lift coefficient, which reduces the stalling speed. As a consequence, the take-off speeds are reduced (the same lift will be created at smaller air speed due to greater lift coefficient). This will reduce the take-off run. Flap extension during landings provides several advantages by: producing greater lift and permitting lower landing speed; producing greater drag, permitting a steep descent angle without airspeed increase. => Reducing the length of the landing roll. The down side of the use of flaps is that it generates more parasite drag: We get our best angle of climb and, therefore, our best gradient where there is the biggest gap between the thrust available and thrust required. The parasite drag from the extended flap closes the gap and the climb angle and climb gradient will reduce => go around performance is deteriorated. Hence as soon as we can after take off we accelerate and retract the flap and climb clean. Thus, we can conclude that the best climb gradient will be achieved using the least amount of flaps.

content.question: In a steady descending flight (descent angle 3) equilibrium of forces acting on the aeroplane is given: (T = THRUST, D = DRAG, W = WEIGHT)

options.A: T-W cos 3 = D
options.B: T+W sin 3 = D
options.C: T-D=W sin 3
options.D: T+D= - W sin 3

key_points: In a steady descent, thrust is reduced
As a result, the aircraft slows down due to a reduced forward force (Thrust) in comparison to the backward force (Drag)
In order for the aircraft to maintain speed and be in a steady descent, the forward component of weight must be increased to balance the Drag
learning.explanation: In a steady descent, thrust is reduced. As a result, the aircraft slows down due to a reduced forward force (Thrust) in comparison to the backward force (Drag). In order for the aircraft to maintain speed and be in a steady descent, the forward component of weight must be increased to balance the Drag. This is achieved by lowering the nose (increasing descent angle y) until this component of weight increases providing enough forward force to balance the drag. At this point, the backward and forward forces are balanced. Drag (D) is balanced by the Thrust (T) and Weight component (W sin y) - "y" being the angle of descent. Resulting on the following equation: D = T + W sin y In this case, Descent angle = 3. Therefore, balance is represented: D = T + W sin 3

content.question: Which of the following factors leads to the maximum flight time of a glide?

options.B: Low mass.
options.C: High mass.
options.D: Tailwind.

key_points: The best glide angle occurs at VMD, flying at this speed will give the best range in a glide

Glide angle (and glide range) itself is independent of aircraft mass - provided the aircraft glides at VMD, since it is the lift over drag (L/D) ratio that determines the gliding range and it is unchanged with mass
However, a Speed faster or slower than VMD will lead to steeper glide angles
learning.explanation: The best glide angle occurs at VMD, flying at this speed will give the best range in a glide. Glide angle (and glide range) itself is independent of aircraft mass - provided the aircraft glides at VMD, since it is the lift over drag (L/D) ratio that determines the gliding range and it is unchanged with mass. However, a Speed faster or slower than VMD will lead to steeper glide angles. Glide angle = CD / CL GLIDING DISTANCE Wind speed is an important practical influence on gliding distance over the surface. With a tailwind, the glide distance achieved will be increased as a result of the increased groundspeed. Whereas with a headwind, it will be reduced because of the consequently slower groundspeed. GLIDING TIME The aircraft's mass varies the time the aircraft will glide for. The heavier the aircraft is, the higher the airspeed must be to obtain the same glide ratio (higher VMD) => Glide duration will be decreased. If two aircraft have the same L/D ratio but different weights and start a glide from the same altitude, the heavier aircraft gliding at a higher airspeed will arrive at the same touchdown point in a shorter time. However, both aircraft will cover the same distance but the lighter one will take a longer time to do so. SUMMARY: Glide Distance (Varies with wind) => Tailwind increases glide distance => Headwind decreases glide distance Glide Duration (Varies with mass) => Low mass increases glide duration => High mass decreases glide duration

content.question: Which of these combinations would provide the lowest specific fuel consumption (SFC)?

options.A: Low altitude, low temperature
options.B: High altitude, high temperature
options.C: Low altitude, high temperature
options.D: High altitude, low temperature

key_points: Note: This should be asking specifically about jet engines, which would fit closest to the learning objectives, and would fit the answer from feedback correctly
Unfortunately, the question does not mention this
We will assume that they are asking about jet engines, but please do tell us in the comments or by email (info@atplquestions
learning.explanation: Note: This should be asking specifically about jet engines, which would fit closest to the learning objectives, and would fit the answer from feedback correctly. Unfortunately, the question does not mention this. We will assume that they are asking about jet engines, but please do tell us in the comments or by email (info@atplquestions.com) if this is the same if you see it in the exam. It may be worth commenting on this in the exam (if available) or appealing if you get it wrong, as it is misleading. Engine efficiency can be measured by a value called the Specific Fuel Consumption. This value tells us how much fuel the engine burns per unit of thrust produced. As we want low fuel burn for high thrust, the lower the SFC, the better. The calculation for SFC is via the formula: SFC = Fuel Flow/Thrust The way to make the SFC lower (more efficient) is by operating the engine in cold temperatures, and at high RPM. The cold temperatures bit of the answer is therefore very simple. However, the best altitude (low or high) requires another step. Above we mentioned that the engine like to run at high RPM to improve SFC. This is the same at all altitudes, but the problem is that the engines are far too powerful to run high RPM at low altitudes, and would quickly cause most jets to overspeed, or just run at very high drag speeds. Therefore, we want to fly at high altitudes, where the high RPM of the engines produces the correct amount of thrust for us to fly at a reasonable cruising speed, with lower drag, and better range (This also coincides with colder temperatures, which are good for SFC). Technically, this doesn't change the SFC much, but practically, it makes a huge difference to our overall efficiency, and our range.

content.question: Which of the following statements is correct during failure of the critical engine?

options.A: VMC increases with altitude.
options.B: VY decreases.
options.C: If flying at VMC, you should be able to maintain heading and altitude with no more than 5° bank.
options.D: Service ceiling remains the same.

key_points: Following the engine failure, there is a progressive increase in parasite drag, which leads to an increase in parasite power (parasite drag x TAS)
Consequently, the right hand side of the power curve lifts up and VY decreases ( “If flying at VMC, you should be able to maintain heading and altitude with no more than 5° bank
“ Incorrect
learning.explanation: Following the engine failure, there is a progressive increase in parasite drag, which leads to an increase in parasite power (parasite drag x TAS). Consequently, the right hand side of the power curve lifts up and VY decreases ( “If flying at VMC, you should be able to maintain heading and altitude with no more than 5° bank. “ Incorrect. VMC is the calibrated airspeed, at which, when the critical engine is suddenly made inoperative, it is possible to maintain control of the aeroplane with that engine still inoperative, and maintain straight flight with an angle of bank not more than 5º. It does not mention anything about maintaining altitude. “VMC increases with altitude” Incorrect. If asymmetric thrust is high, VMC will be high. Asymmetric thrust is higher at low altitudes, therefore VMC would be expected to decrease with altitude. “Service ceiling remains the same” Incorrect. An engine failure will result in loss of thrust from the failed engine. Parasite drag will also increase – from the rudder and the windmilling engine. The total loss of thrust can be as much as 80%, if we account for the extra drag which needs to be opposed. Based on the above, we can immediately exclude one of the options => The Service ceiling will not remain the same, it will reduce.

learning.explanation: Learning Objective 032.01.02.02.10: Define an aeroplane’s ‘specific range’ (SR) in terms of nautical air miles (NAM) per unit of fuel, and ‘specific range over the ground’ (SRG) in terms of nautical ground miles (NGM) per unit of fuel. SPECIFIC RANGE (SR) There are two types of specific range, specific air range (SAR) and specific ground range (SGR). Specific air range is the distance through the air covered per unit of fuel burnt, while SGR is the ground distance per unit of fuel. The difference is due to wind, in the same way that groundspeed is just true airspeed plus/minus wind. options.B: increases the best rate of climb.
options.C: increases the angle of flight path during climb.
options.D: increases the maximum endurance.

key_points: A steady (continuous) head wind (or tail wind) will not affect your climb rate, only your climb angle
The angle of climb flight path is the angle the plane is flying with respect to the ground
When flying into a steady headwind the ground speed will be lower at the same airspeed
learning.explanation: A steady (continuous) head wind (or tail wind) will not affect your climb rate, only your climb angle. The angle of climb flight path is the angle the plane is flying with respect to the ground. When flying into a steady headwind the ground speed will be lower at the same airspeed. But the climb rate will be the same. Therefore, if you're climbing at the same rate, but moving forward at a slower rate, the angle will be steeper. It means you will reach a specific altitude in the same time interval, but your ground distance will be affected. In the case of a Headwind, your ground distance will be reduced. Note: A headwind will not affect the climb angle or rate of climb, but it will affect the angle of climb relative to the ground => it will make the flight path angle steeper.

options.B: By increasing the holding speed and thrust to anticipate for the increased drag due to the film of water on the aeroplane.
options.C: By reducing the aeroplane’s pitch to anticipate for a pitch-up moment caused by water downpour on the tail.
options.D: By reducing the holding speed and thrust to prevent a potential engine flame-out caused by ingesting a lot of water.

key_points: IMPORTANT NOTE: This question was copied from POF following student feedback
However, it appears to be beyond the scope of the Performance syllabus
Please inform us if you encounter this question in your 032 Performance exam
learning.explanation: IMPORTANT NOTE: This question was copied from POF following student feedback. However, it appears to be beyond the scope of the Performance syllabus. Please inform us if you encounter this question in your 032 Performance exam. The airframe may become contaminated by ice, frost or water either whilst it is in flight or when standing on the ground. HEAVY RAIN Heavy rain has the following effects on aeroplane performance: - The impingement and rapid accumulation of water sufficiently distorts the shape of the upper wing surface and diminishes the total lift by up to 30% of its normal value. - The impact of the rain on an aeroplane in the landing configuration decreases the aircraft’s forward speed. - When operating in such conditions a jet engine is slow to respond to rapid demands for thrust. - The mass of the rain can increase the aircraft mass momentarily. The total effect of these factors for any aeroplane experiencing such weather conditions is to produce a much lower level of performance. The mass increase raises the stalling speed, whilst the reduced lift and increased drag together reduce the forward speed achieved. An additional consideration, while not affecting stall speed, is the effect of the impact of heavy rain on the aircraft. Momentum will be lost and airspeed will decrease, requiring increased thrust. At the same time, heavy rain will also be driving the aircraft downwards.

content.question: For (1) _____ aeroplane(s), the take-off distance calculations must take into account (2) _____ and (3) _____.
